CHAPTER 905
Excavations
905.01   Definitions.
905.02   Permit required.
905.03   Insurance.
905.04   Supervision of excavations.
905.05   Protection of public by barricades.
905.06   Return of deposit.
905.07   Exception.
905.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Openings by Municipality - see Ohio R.C. 723.02
         Liability for damages - see Ohio R.C. 723.49 et seq.
         Barricades and warning lights - see GEN. OFF.
521.03
   905.01  DEFINITIONS.
   Wherever the words streets, boulevards, avenues and alleys are used, such
words mean that land lying between private lot lines and land dedicated for
public use.
(Ord. 1956-64. Passed 9-10-56.)
   905.02  PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Before any person, other than a duly authorized City officer or employee or
other than provided for in a contract with the City, makes any excavation in
any street, boulevard, avenue, alley, highway or other public ground in the
City, or removes the surface of any sidewalk or any part thereof, or opens any
sidewalk in the City, such person shall file with the Building Commissioner an
application accurately indicating the location, kind and extent of such
proposed excavation or removal of sidewalk, the number, purpose and size of
such, removals or excavations which are desired or necessary, and furnish any
other information requested by the Commissioner and obtain a permit. If any
excavations are for a purpose other than pursuant to a contract with the City,
the applicant shall deposit with the Director of  Finance an amount sufficient
to cover the cost of and supervision of backfilling, repairing, restoring and
relaying the pavement or hard surface or the sidewalk, as the case may be,
together with the cost of any new material, as the same is estimated by the
Commissioner or any other person designated by the Mayor or Director of Public
Service to make such estimate.
(Ord. 1964-87. Passed 12-28-64.)
   905.03  INSURANCE.
   Before any excavation permit is issued, the applicant shall also deposit
with the Building Commissioner an insurance policy, issued by a company
authorized to write insurance in the State of Ohio, designating the City as the
insured therein, by the terms of which the City is saved harmless from all
claims for bodily injury within the limits of one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000) for each person and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) for
each accident and for property damage claims in the amount of ten thousand
dollars ($10,000) for each accident arising or growing out of the street
excavation or removal of the surface of any sidewalk or excavation in any
sidewalk or in the prosecution of the work for which the permit is obtained or
in any manner arising or growing out of the work necessary or incident to the
issuance of the permit or that may be occasioned by reason of any excavation or
anything else done pursuant to the permit.
   905.04  SUPERVISION OF EXCAVATIONS.
   All excavations made within the street lines or sidewalk removed shall be
subject to the directions of and under the supervision of the Director of
Public Service or the Building Commissioner. All paving, material, flagging,
curbing and ballasting shall be carefully removed and preserved, and after the
work is done, as contemplated by the application for the permit heretofore
referred to, the trench or excavation shall be refilled, in accordance with the
directions of the Director or the Building Commissioner, and the flagging,
concrete, paving or other paving material shall be properly replaced under the
supervision of the Director or the Building Commissioner, but at the
applicant's expense.
(Ord. 1956-64. Passed 9-10-56.)
   905.05  PROTECTION OF PUBLIC BY BARRICADES.
   All excavations, obstructions or locations where the sidewalk is removed
shall be carefully guarded, protected or barricaded at all times, and during
the night season shall be defined by red colored lights and such other
precautions shall be taken as shall be necessary to guard against accidents. In
this respect the Director of Public Service or the Building Commissioner may
issue any additional orders as he may deem proper which shall be implicitly and
promptly complied with. At all times work shall be done so as to cause the
least inconvenience to property owners and the general public.
(Ord. 1956-64. Passed 9-10-56.)
   905.06  RETURN OF DEPOSIT.
   When any work under any permit is completed and all the mandates of this
chapter have been complied with and all orders of the City have been fulfilled
with respect to the work or the object for which the permit was obtained, the
Director of Finance shall issue a warrant to return the excess of the cost to
the person who made the deposit. If the deposit is insufficient to reimburse
the City, as specified in Section
905.02, the Director shall certify the deficiency, and such deficiency shall be
paid by the permit applicant to the Director.
(Ord. 1964-87. Passed 12-28-64.)
   905.07  EXCEPTION.
   Nothing contained in this chapter shall be deemed applicable to any
contracts with the City with respect to street excavations.
(Ord. 1956-64. Passed 9-10-56.)
   905.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than ten days, or both.
(Ord. 1956-64. Passed 9-10-56.)
CHAPTER 909
Curbs and Driveways
909.01   Service Director to approve curb changes.
909.02   Specifications for driveway approaches.
909.03   Permit; fee.
909.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
            Sidewalks - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
913
   909.01  SERVICE DIRECTOR TO APPROVE CURB CHANGES.
   (a)    Any alteration, cutting, change, repair, removal or replacement of
curbs shall be under the control and direction of the Director of Public
Service and shall be done by a qualified person and approved by the Director.
   (b)    Curbs shall not be altered, cut, changed or removed to allow traffic
to enter or leave the street over an installed catch basin.
   (c)    The length and location of each curb cut and lowered curb shall be
subject to the approval of the Director.
(Ord. 1991-63. Passed 11-25-91.)
   909.02  SPECIFICATIONS FOR DRIVEWAY APPROACHES.
   Driveway approaches shall be a minimum of fourteen feet wide at the curb or
curb line, the subgrade thereof shall consist of granulated slag, gravel or
stone, the minimum thickness of which shall be three inches, and the surface of
which shall be of rigid construction not less than six inches thick. The
installation of such driveway approaches shall be under the control and
direction of the Director of Public Service, who may require that the subgrade
thereof shall consist of granulated slag, gravel or stone more than three
inches thick and who may also specify the character of the surface thereof
which may be in excess of six inches.
   909.03  PERMIT; FEE.
   The alteration, cutting, change, repair, removal or replacement of a curb or
curbs contemplated by Section
909.01 and the construction of driveway approaches contemplated by Section
909.02 shall be performed under permits obtained from the Director of Public
Service and the fee for each such permit is five dollars ($5.00).
(Ord. 1982-37. Passed 5-10-82.)
   909.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than ten days, or both.
(Ord. 1956-64. Passed 9-10-56.)
CHAPTER 913
Sidewalk Construction
913.01   Location and widths.
913.02   Specifications; grading.
913.03   Changing sidewalks.
913.04   Permit; fees.
913.05   Cash deposit and bond.
913.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Construction or repair at owner's expense - see Ohio R.C. 729.01 et
seq.
         Notice to construct or repair sidewalks - see Ohio R.C. 729.03 et seq.
         Excavations - see S. U. & P. S. Ch.
905
   913.01  LOCATION AND WIDTHS.
   All sidewalks shall be under the direction of the Director of Public
Service. Sidewalks shall be located six inches from the right-of-way line
unless otherwise determined by Council.
   The width of all sidewalks shall be five feet, except in the following
cases:
   (a)    Sidewalks shall be four feet in width in rights of way of forty feet
or less.
   (b)    Sidewalks shall be two and one-half feet in width in streets or
alleys of sixteen feet or less.
   (c)    Where certain sides of streets or alleys are substantially improved
with sidewalks, the width of any sidewalk shall be determined by Council in its
resolution of necessity for the construction of sidewalks on the sides of such
streets or alleys or shall be determined by the Director so as to conform with
the existing width of the sidewalks on the side or sides of such streets or
alleys.
(Ord. 1962-79. Passed 10-22-62.)
   913.02  SPECIFICATIONS; GRADING.
   (a)    All sidewalks hereafter improved by placing walks with a permanent
surfacing on any public highway or street within the City shall be so improved
by constructing the sidewalks with concrete four inches thick, except at
driveways where the thickness shall be six inches, both with two inches of sand
base or approved equal and in accordance with the specifications prescribed by
the Director of Public Service, and shall be of the width prescribed by
resolution of Council or as directed by the Director of Public Service where no
resolution has been passed. The sidewalk shall be laid so that the top surface
shall be properly roughened, so that the same shall be prevented from becoming
slippery when covered with moisture, and the roughened finish shall be of such
character as in the judgment of the Director will effectually prevent at any
time a slippery condition of the walk.
   (b)    Any grading necessary between the walks, as laid, and the curb line,
or between the walks and the edge of the sidewalk space as herein established,
shall be done at the time of laying the walks, so as to leave the sidewalk
space at the grade hereinafter described.
   (c)    The sidewalks as improved shall coincide with the line described as
follows: Beginning at the curb line with the established curb grade as
determined by the City Engineer, thence extending to the street line at right
angles to the curb line, with a rise of three-eighths of an inch to the foot
with the following exceptions:
      (1)    At street intersections where the grade of the intersecting street
prevents compliance with the above provisions, the walk shall be laid under the
direction and to the acceptance of the Director or the Engineer.
      (2)    At the direction of the Director, grades may be varied in
relationship to the curb as is determined necessary.
         (Ord. 1962-79. Passed 10-22-62.)
   913.03  CHANGING SIDEWALKS.
   (a)    Any sidewalk heretofore laid shall not be raised or lowered without
the approval of the City Engineer or the Director of Public Service, and all
sidewalks hereafter laid shall be in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter and under the supervision of the City Engineer or the Director of
Public Service.
   
   (b)    No curb line or grade for curb shall be changed, except by the
direction and the written consent of the Director or Engineer.
   (c)    Any sidewalk laid on any public street or highway within the City in
a manner inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter shall, upon the
recommendation of the Director, be ordered relaid to the proper grade, upon the
failure of the property owner to make the change so ordered within the time
specified in the notice.
(Ord. 1953-66. Passed 11-23-53.)
   913.04  PERMIT; FEES.
   (a)    No sidewalk shall be improved, replaced or relaid unless a permit for
so doing shall have been obtained from the Director of Public Service or
Building Commissioner. The permit shall stipulate the character of surfacing or
walk to be laid, the extent of the same and the sublot and house number, or
adequate measurements identifying the location where no such numbers have been
established, in front of which the walk is to be laid or relaid. All concrete
surfacing of sidewalks shall be subject to the inspection of duly authorized
City inspectors, who shall see that the requirements of the approved
specifications of the sidewalk surfacing are fulfilled. For furnishing the
inspection, there may be collected from the property owner an amount or fee not
to exceed the cost thereof.
   A fee of five dollars ($5.00) must be paid to the Director or the Building
Commissioner before construction begins. However, there shall be no fee
required hereunder when such improvement is made pursuant to a notice issued in
accordance with a resolution of necessity adopted by Council, requesting such
improvement be made.
   (b)    The owner of land in front of which a permit to improve a sidewalk
has been given may request that the Director establish the grade or line upon
which the improvement is to be made.
   (c)    For establishing the line and grade of the sidewalk improvement by
the Director, in accordance with the land owner's request, there shall be
collected from the owner a fee based upon the following rates:
      (1)    For each lineal foot of sidewalk for which the grade is given, ten
cents (10¢).
      (2)    For each lineal foot of sidewalk for which the line is furnished,
ten cents (10¢).
      (3)    For each lineal foot of sidewalk for which both line and grade are
furnished, twenty cents (20¢).
      (4)    The minimum fee charged in any case shall be fifteen dollars
($15.00).
   (d)    All amounts collected for inspection or engineering fees shall accrue
to the credit of the General Fund.
(Ord. 1974-33. Passed 7-12-74.)
   913.05  CASH DEPOSIT AND BOND.
   Each person who engages in the work of laying, relaying or repairing
sidewalks upon the City streets shall, before engaging in any such work or
employment, make a cash deposit of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and shall give
bond to the City in the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each fifty
thousand square feet of sidewalk estimated to be laid, relaid or repaired, or
for any fractional part thereof, on condition that the City shall be saved
harmless from any loss or expenditure in any manner arising from the conduct of
such persons, in the work of laying, relaying or repairing sidewalks, and from
any loss or damage which may arise by reason of any obstructions, excavations,
barriers, guards or other objects or materials placed or deposited in the
street during the progress of the work, or the expense of removing the same or
cleaning the street or sidewalk, and from any loss or damage arising from any
acts, negligence or default of such persons, and conditioned further upon the
sidewalks so laid, relaid or repaired remaining in good condition to the
satisfaction of the Director of Public Service of the City, for a full period
of two years from the year of the laying, relaying or repairing the sidewalks,
and conditioned upon such person immediately upon the appearance of any
defects, disintegration or fault in the sidewalks appearing and due to any
acts, omissions or default of the one laying the same, being immediately
repaired and restored to a good and proper condition to the satisfaction of the
Director of Public Service, as to such defects as may appear at any time within
two years of the year of laying, relaying or repairing the sidewalks. The bond
and deposit shall cover all of the foregoing matters which may arise or be
occasioned at any time within two years of the calendar year within which the
work is done.
   The cash deposit, less any expenses which may have been charged against the
same by the City, shall be returned whenever the person entitled to lay, relay
or repair sidewalks and having made the deposit, in accordance with the
provisions prescribed, informs the Director of Public Service in writing that
he no longer intends to engage in such work.
(Ord. 1953-66. Passed 11-23-53.)
   913.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever neglects to comply with any provision of this chapter, or engages in
sidewalk construction work without a permit, shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense and the further sum of five dollars
($5.00) for each day the violation continues in the discretion of the court.
CHAPTER 914
Sidewalk Maintenance and Repair
914.01   Purpose; state of disrepair and nuisance prohibited.
914.02   Owners of abutting property to keep sidewalks in repair.
914.03   Notice of repair.
914.04   Contents of notice.
914.05   Emergencies.
914.06   Property owners to be billed.
914.07   Assessment against abutting property.
914.08   Appeal.
CROSS REFERENCES
Sidewalk construction - see S.U. & P.S.
Ch. 913
   914.01  PURPOSE; STATE OF DISREPAIR AND NUISANCE PROHIBITED.
   (a)   The terms of Sections
914.01 through
914.08 shall be construed for the benefit of the public using of the sidewalks,
driveway approaches, and crosswalks but shall not be arbitrary as against the
property owner.
 
   (b)   A state of disrepair and nuisance shall be considered such condition
as would prevent the safe use of the public sidewalk, driveway approach, and
crosswalk hereinafter set forth.
      (1)   A raise of depression between sections in the sidewalk, driveway
approach, or crosswalk in excess of 3/4 inch.
      (2)   Loose, broken portions of concrete in the sidewalk, driveway
approach, or crosswalk which provides an unstable walking area or broken
portions which have been removed from the sidewalk, driveway approach, or
crosswalk.
      (3)   Areas of sidewalk, driveway approach, or crosswalk that have been
caused to sink or tilt from its normal position due to undermining or sinking
of subsurface that provides unsafe walking conditions.
      (4)   Areas of sidewalk, driveway approach, or crosswalk that have become
broken, raised, or tilted by roots of trees to such extent that the public
safety would be affected.
      (5)   Areas of sidewalk, driveway approach, or crosswalk that contain
pitted or deteriorated slabs where water can lie and freeze and/or indentations
which are capable of causing a person to stumble and/or fall.
      (6)   Concrete aprons and/or walks that contain cracks that are one-
quarter inch (1/4") wide or more which are topped with asphalt or other type of
material. 
         (Ord. 2004-6.  Passed 2-23-04.)
   914.02  OWNERS OF ABUTTING PROPERTY TO KEEP SIDEWALKS IN REPAIR.
   Where land abuts on a street where there is a paved sidewalk or abuts on a
crosswalk or driveway approach, the owner of such land shall be jointly and
severally responsible for causing the sidewalk, driveway approach, or crosswalk
abutting such land to be kept in repair and free from nuisance.  (Ord. 2004-6. 
Passed 2-23-04.)
   914.03  NOTICE OF REPAIR.
   When the Director of Public Service finds that such sidewalk, driveway
approach, or crosswalk is in a state of disrepair or is not free from nuisance,
he shall notify the owner of the abutting property, in writing, to have the
necessary construction, reconstruction, or repair made.  This notice shall be
served on the owner or his agent, personally or by registered mail sent to the
last known address of the owner and by leaving a copy of the notice with the
occupant of the premises if occupied or left in a conspicuous place on the
premises if unoccupied.  For purposes of such service, any person charged with
the collection of rents or payment of taxes on the property or having general
control of it in any way shall be considered the agent of the owner.  (Ord.
2004-6.  Passed 2-23-04.)
   914.04  CONTENTS OF NOTICE.
   The notice provided for in Section
914.03 shall identify the property and give the location of the sidewalk,
driveway approach, or crosswalk and the period of time allowed the property
owner to have the work done.  Such time shall be reasonable, but shall not be
less than 15 days for construction and not less than five days for repairs.
(Ord. 2004-6.  Passed 2-23-04.)
   914.05  EMERGENCIES.
   In case of emergency, the Director of Public Service is authorized to have
temporary repairs made, or to barricade and red-light the area, or otherwise
provide for the public safety.  The reasonable cost of emergency repair and
protection shall be charged against the abutting property and shall be
collected as provided for in Sections
914.06 and
914.07.
(Ord. 2004-6.  Passed 2-23-04.)
   914.06  PROPERTY OWNERS TO BE BILLED.
   Upon completion by the City of any sidewalk, driveway approach, or crosswalk
repair, construction, or reconstruction as provided for in Sections
914.04 and
914.05, the owner of the abutting property, or his agent, shall be billed for
the reasonable cost and expense of the work.  The bill shall include:
   (a)   All construction costs, including emergency.
   (b)   A charge for administrative costs of five dollars ($5.00) or ten
percent (10%) of the construction costs, whichever is greater, not to exceed
thirty-five dollars ($35.00).  (Ord. 2004-6.  Passed 2-23-04.)
   914.07  ASSESSMENT AGAINST ABUTTING PROPERTY.
   Bills issued under
914.06 shall be payable within thirty days from the date of such bill.  Bills
not paid within thirty days shall be certified to the County Auditor to be an
assessment against the abutting property.  (Ord. 2004-6.  Passed 2-23-04.)
   914.08  APPEAL.
   (a)   A property owner protesting any notice to repair provided for herein
shall file a written notice of appeal to the Board of Zoning Appeals prior to
the time set for compliance.  The Board of Zoning Appeals shall hear the
protest as soon as practicable without charge and without requiring public
notice to be given.
 
   (b)   The Board of Zoning Appeals is authorized to hear evidence and
determine if the provisions of the notice of repair are reasonable.
(Ord. 2004-6.  Passed 2-23-04.)
CHAPTER 917
Sluice Pipes
917.01   Installation requirement.
917.02   Pipe to be free from obstructions.
917.03   Service of notice.
917.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Notice to remove obstructions - see GEN. OFF.
521.05
         Solid waste obstructing watercourse - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
   917.01  INSTALLATION REQUIREMENT.
   Every owner or occupant of abutting lots and lands on any public
thoroughfare or street in the City which is not improved with stone or concrete
curbing shall cause to be constructed under the drive serving the lot or land a
metal corrugated sluice pipe of not less than eight inches in diameter. The
pipe shall be installed at the edge of the thoroughfare or street and in such a
manner as to permit the surface water of the thoroughfare or street to freely
pass through, and in accordance with the directions of the Director of Public
Service.
(Ord. 1949-7. Passed 5-9-49.)
   917.02  PIPE TO BE FREE FROM OBSTRUCTIONS.
   It shall be the duty of every owner or occupant of land abutting a public
thoroughfare to keep the pipe free from obstructions so as to permit water to
pass freely through.
(Ord. 1949-7. Passed 5-9-49.)
   917.03  SERVICE OF NOTICE.
   Any police officer or the Director of Public Service is authorized to serve
the notice provided for in Section
917.99.
(Ord. 1949-7. Passed 5-9-49.)
   917.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever fails to install a sluice pipe or fails to remove obstructions
therein within fifteen days from service of written notice to do so shall be
fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day's violation of the
order shall be a separate offense.

   921.01  RESERVED.
   EDITOR’S NOTE:  This section is reserved for future legislation.
ON PRIVATE PROPERTY
   921.02  TRIMMING OF TREES, SHRUBBERY.
   The owner of every lot or parcel of land upon which a tree, plant or
shrubbery stands with any part thereof upon or overhanging a public street or
sidewalk shall conform to the regulations in this chapter; otherwise, the City
shall cause such trees to be trimmed or cut down and removed in accordance with
the regulations and assess the cost against the owner of the lot or parcel of
land.
   (a)    The owner shall trim or cause to be trimmed the tree, plant or
shrubbery so that a clear height of eight feet between the lowest branch and
the street or sidewalk is maintained.
   (b)    The owner shall trim or remove, as the case may require, every dead,
decayed or broken tree, plant, shrubbery, or part thereof, so that the same
shall not fall to the street or sidewalk.
   (c)    The owner shall cut down and remove any tree, plant, shrubbery, or
any part thereof, as may be necessary to provide a clear and unobstructed view
of traffic from all directions at any street, intersection, or to abate any
nuisance to protect life, limb and property of persons, drivers of any vehicles
or pedestrians using the street or sidewalk.
(Ord. 1956-85. Passed 11-26-56.)
   921.03  REMOVAL OF WEEDS.
   The owner, occupant or person having the charge or management of any lot or
parcel of land, whether the same is improved or unimproved, vacant or occupied,
within three days of written notice to do so, shall cut or destroy or cause to
be cut or destroyed, any offensive, noxious or poisonous weeds, vines or
grasses growing upon any such lot or parcel of land and prevent the same from
blooming or going to seed or exceeding a height of eight inches.
(Ord. 2008-58.  Passed 6-23-08.)
   921.04  CITY MAY DO WORK.
   If any tree, plant, shrubbery, or any part thereof, or any weeds, vines or
grasses are not trimmed or removed in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter, then the Mayor is authorized to enforce the provisions of this
chapter, and to cause to be trimmed or removed the tree, plant, shrubbery, or
part thereof, and cut and remove all grass and weeds.
(Ord. 1956-85. Passed 11-26-56.)
   921.05  COLLECTION OF COSTS.
   (a)   Whenever any tree, plant, shrubbery, or part thereof, or weeds and
grass are growing in violation of Sections
921.02 and
921.03 and are trimmed or removed by the City, after the work is done, the City
shall give three-days’ notice by regular mail to the owner of the lot or parcel
of land at his last known address to pay the cost.  The notice shall be
accompanied by a statement of the amount of cost incurred, and in the event the
amount is not paid within thirty days after the mailing of the notice, then the
amount shall be certified to the County Auditor for collection, the same as
other taxes and assessments are collected.
   (b)   The cost to the owner of a residential property for cutting, trimming,
or removal shall be a minimum charge of two hours at the rate of $125.00 per
hour of work for a minimum fee of $250.00.  The cost to the owner of a
commercial/industrial/business property for cutting, trimming, or removal shall
be a minimum charge of two hours of work at the rate of $225.00 per hour of
work, for a minimum fee of $450.00. 
(Ord. 2018-09.  Passed 3-26-18.)
   921.06  TREES NEAR SEWERS; REMOVAL.
   Any tree, regardless of type or family, located within the City right-of-way
or within the City’s easement, that infiltrates any storm or sanitary sewer,
shall be removed by the City at the City’s cost.
(Ord. 2014-07.  Passed 5-12-14.)
   921.07  TREES DAMAGING ADJOINING PROPERTY; REMOVAL. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
921.07 was repealed by Ordinance 2019-54, passed December 9, 2019.)
   921.08  SPRAYING.
   The Mayor shall have the power to enter upon any private grounds and to
cause to be sprayed or otherwise treated any tree, shrub or plant infected or
infested by any parasite or insect pest when it is necessary in the opinion of
the Mayor to do so to prevent the breeding or scattering of any parasite or
animal pest and to prevent danger therefrom to shade trees, plants and
shrubbery planted in the streets, alleys, public parks and public grounds.
Whenever in the opinion of the Mayor, trimming treatment or removal of any
tree, plant or shrub located on private grounds is deemed prudent, the Mayor
shall have power to trim, treat or remove any such tree, shrub or plant.
(Ord. 1954-68. Passed 9-27-54.)
ON PRIVATE OR PUBLIC PROPERTY
   921.09  CERTAIN TREES PROHIBITED.
   No poplar, cottonwood, willow, box elder, basswood, silver maple, honey
locust or catalpa trees shall be planted within the limits of the City.
(Ord. 1972-60. Passed 9-25-72.)
   921.10  RESERVED.
   EDITOR’S NOTE:  This section is reserved for future legislation.
ON PUBLIC PROPERTY
   921.11  POWERS OF MAYOR.
   The Mayor shall have the right to plant, trim, preserve and remove all trees
within the lines of all streets, alleys, and public grounds as may be necessary
to insure safety or preserve the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds.
The Mayor may cause any tree or plant life which is in an unsafe condition, or
which by reason of its nature, is injurious to sewers or other improvements, or
is affected by any injurious scale or other pest, to be removed.
(Ord. 1954-68. Passed 9-27-54.)
   921.12  PLANTING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall plant or set out any shade tree, shrub or plant, or cause or
authorize or procure any person to plant or set out any shade tree, shrub or
other plant in or on any part of any public street, public park or public
ground without first obtaining a written permit to do so from the Mayor, or
without complying in all respects with the conditions provided in the permit.
(Ord. 1954-68. Passed 9-27-54.)
   921.13  DAMAGE, PERMIT TO TRIM OR TREAT.
   No person without a written permit from the Mayor shall cut, break, climb or
injure any tree or portion of any tree or any shrub or plant planted or growing
in any public street, public park. or public ground, or cause, authorize or
procure any person to do the same. No person shall injure, misuse or remove, or
cause, authorize or procure any person to injure, misuse or remove any device
set for the protection of any tree, shrub or plant. Any person desiring for any
lawful purpose to cut, prune, treat with a view of its preservation from
disease or insect, or trim any tree, shrub or plant, may apply to the Mayor,
and if, in the judgment of the Mayor, the desired cutting, pruning, treatment
or trimming appears necessary and the proposed method and workmanship are such
as the Mayor approves, the Mayor may issue a written permit for such work. Any
work proposed under the written permit must be performed in strict accordance
with the terms thereof.
(Ord. 1954-68. Passed 9-27-54.)
   921.14  ELECTRICAL CONDUCTORS.
   No person shall cause, authorize or procure a wire or other conductor
charged with electricity, to come into contact with any tree, shrub or plant in
a public street, public park or public ground in such manner as may injure,
destroy, abrade or kill such tree, shrub or plant.
(Ord. 1954-68. Passed 9-27-54.)
   921.15  SIGNS, ROPES AND WIRES.
   No person shall attach or keep attached to any tree or shrub in any public
street, public park or public ground or to the guard or stake intended for
protection of such tree or shrub, any rope, wire, sign or any other device
whatsoever, except for the purpose of protecting the  tree or shrub or the
public.
(Ord. 1954-68. Passed 9-27-54.)
   921.16  HARMFUL SUBSTANCES PROHIBITED.
   (a)    No person owning or using, or having control or charge of gas or
other substance deleterious to tree or plant life, shall allow such gas or
other deleterious substance to come into contact with the soil surrounding the
roots of any tree or plant life in any public ground in such manner as may
injure the tree or plant life.
   (b)    No person shall cause, authorize or permit any brine, water, oil,
liquid dye or other substance deleterious to tree or plant life to lie, leak,
pour, flow or drip on or into the soil about the base of any tree in any public
ground, or onto the sidewalk, road or pavement therein at a point whence such
substance may by lying on, or by flowing, dripping or seeping into the soil, or
in any other manner whatsoever, injure the tree or plant life; or cause or
permit such lying, leaking, flowing, dripping, seeping or injuring.
   (c)    No person, except with the written permit of the Mayor, shall place
or maintain upon any public ground any stone, cement or other material or
substance in such manner as may obstruct the free access of air and water to
the roots of any tree, shrub or ornamental plant in any street, public park or
public ground. Unless otherwise provided for in the written permit as herein
provided, there must be maintained about the base of the trunk of each shade
tree in public ground at least six square feet of open ground for a tree three
inches in diameter, and for every two inches of increase of such diameter,
there must be an increase of at least one square foot of open ground.
(Ord. 1954-68. Passed 9-27-54.)
   921.17  KILLING OR REMOVING PROHIBITED; EXCEPTION; PERMIT.
   No person shall kill or remove, or cause or authorize the death or removal
of any tree, shrub or plant growing in any public ground. Any person desiring
for any lawful purpose to remove any tree, shrub or plant in any public ground
may apply to the Mayor and if, in the judgment of the Mayor, the desired
removal appears necessary, the Mayor may thereupon issue a written permit
therefor. Any work proposed under such written permit must be performed in
strict accordance with the terms thereof.
(Ord. 1954-68. Passed 9-27-54.)
   921.99  PENALTY.
   (a)    Whoever fails to comply with the requirements of Section
921.03 shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than
fifty dollars ($50.00) for each violation. This penalty shall be imposed in
addition to any charges made under Section
921.05.
   (b)    Whoever violates any other provision of this chapter shall be fined
not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 1980-40. Passed 6-23-80.)
TITLE THREE - Utilities

CHAPTER 931
Utilities Generally
931.01   Tap-in fee.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Right of eminent domain - see Ohio R.C. 719.01 et seq., 743.39 et seq.
      Assessments for sewers - see Ohio R.C. Ch.  729
   931.01  TAP-IN FEE.
   (a)   Wherever public sanitary sewers, storm sewers or water lines have been
constructed and the cost thereof has been wholly or partly paid out of the
funds of the City or the cost thereof has been partially or wholly assessed
against the property and the owner of any abutting property applies for a
permit to tap into any such sewer or water line, no permit shall be issued to
the abutting owner if for any reason an assessment has not been levied against
the property for which the tap is sought, unless such person shall first pay
into the City Treasury a sum equal to the following formula:
      (1)   Sanitary sewer: nine dollars ($9.00) per front foot, plus three
hundred dollars ($300.00) per connection;
      (2)   Storm sewer: ten dollars ($10.00) per front foot;
      (3)   Water line: seven dollars ($7.00) per front foot.
   (b)   The above provisions shall apply only in instances where the property
abuts on an improved street in which the above mentioned improvements have been
constructed.
   (c)   In the event an owner of property applies for a permit to tap into a
storm sewer, sanitary sewer or water line where such improvement(s) does not
abut on the property, the fee to tap into such improvement(s) shall be
determined by Council and shall be based upon the facts in each individual
application.
(Ord.  1998-48.  Passed 6-22-98.)
CHAPTER 935
Sewer Regulations and Rates
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Ordinance 1998-45, passed June 22, 1998, authorized the Mayor
to enter into an agreement with the City of Euclid for the disposal of sewage.
935.01   Purpose; definitions.
935.02   Rates.

CROSS REFERENCES
         Power to construct sewerage system - see Ohio R.C. 715.40, 717.01
         Compulsory connections - see Ohio R.C. 729.06
         Sewerage rates - see Ohio R.C. 729.49, 729.52
         Weekly deposit of rentals collected - see Ohio R.C. 729.52
         Tap-in fees - see S.U. & P.S.
931.01
   935.01  PURPOSE; DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   It is hereby declared necessary for the public health, safety, welfare
and convenience of the City and its inhabitants, to operate the sewerage
system, i.e., the storm and sanitary sewers and appurtenances, as a public
utility and to levy and collect sewer service charges upon all lands, lots and
premises served by such sewerage system, and such charges, when collected,
shall be used for the purposes hereinafter provided.
   (b)   “Sewage” means water or water-borne wastes, and “industrial wastes”
means liquid wastes resulting from any commercial, manufacturing or industrial
operation or process, which water-borne or liquid wastes enter the sewerage
system or any portion thereof of the City.  “Sewerage system” means storm and
sanitary sewers, sewage disposal works, treatment plants, sewage pumping
stations, impounding areas, together with facilities and appurtenances
necessary and proper therefor. 
(Ord.  1961-2.  Passed 2-13-61.)
   935.02  RATES.
   Pursuant to the provisions of Ohio R.C.  729.49 and other related sections
of the Ohio Revised Code, every person, whose premises in the City are drained
by or served by the system of sewerage of the City or whereby the sewage or
industrial wastes or either therefrom are disposed of by the City through its
sewerage system or otherwise, shall pay a sewer service charge or rental charge
as noted below, predicated upon the quantity of metered water used in or upon
such premises for each 100 cubic feet of water or fraction thereof measured
through or by any one water meter, per quarter, whether such water is derived
from a source other than the City water supply or all or any part of such water
is furnished to such premises without charge.  Nothing contained in this
section shall be held to authorize or require the payment of any sewer rental
charge by any tax supported department of the City.
 
Effective date: May 24, 2019  January 1, 2020 January 1, 2021 January 1, 2022
                $3.60 per 100 $4.14 per 100   $4.55 per 100   $4.78 per 100
                cu.ft.        cu.ft.          cu.ft.          cu.ft.
   It is further the intent hereof, that a minimum charge per quarter as noted
as follows shall be charged and collected from all premises served by the
sewerage system of the City.
 
Effective date: May 24, 2019 January 1, 2020 January 1, 2021 January 1, 2022
                $36.00       $41.40          $45.54          $47.82
(Ord. 2019-39.  Passed 9-9-19.)
   935.025 WILLOWICK AND WILLOUGHBY HILLS SANITARY SEWER SERVICE FEES
   (a)   The City of Willowick shall hereafter be charged by the City of
Wickliffe a sanitary sewer fee as follows:

                cu.ft.        cu.ft.          cu.ft.          cu.ft.

Wickliffe a sanitary sewer service fee as follows:

                cu.ft.         cu.ft.          cu.ft.          cu.ft.
   (c)   The City Engineer is hereby authorized to notify the City of Willowick
and the City of Willoughby Hills of such increase and to commence collection of
such sewer service fees and/or to cause such fees to be paid to the City.
(Ord. 2019-39.  Passed 9-9-19.)
   935.026 COMMERCIAL RATE.
   Every commercial and/or business activity, whose premises in the City are
drained by or served by the system of sewerage of the City or whereby the
sewerage or individual wastes or either therefrom, are disposed of by the City
through its sewerage system, or otherwise, shall pay a sewer service or rental
charge as follows, predicated upon the quantity of metered water used in or
upon such premises per each 100 cubic feet of water or less, or none, measured
through or by any one water meter, per quarter, whether such water is derived
from a source other than the City water supply or all or any part of such water
is furnished to such premises without charge.
 
Effective date: May 24, 2019  January 1, 2020 January 1, 2021 January 1, 2022
                $3.92 per 100 $4.51 per 100   $4.96 per 100   $5.21 per 100
                cu.ft.        cu.ft.          cu.ft.          cu.ft.
(Ord. 2019-39.  Passed 9-9-19.)
   935.03  RATE REDUCTION FOR WATER NOT DISCHARGED INTO SYSTEM.
   (a)   No sewer rental charge shall be assessed to those residential
properties within the City using approved septic tank systems for sanitary
sewerage upon that property.
   (b)   Commercial and industrial customers may be exempt from paying sanitary
sewer utility fees if they conform to the rules and regulations that shall be
established by the Director of Public Service.  Minimally, these rules and
regulations shall require the following:
      (1)   The water purchased by any given commercial or industrial customer
shall be used solely in a process making a product for sale.  The City must
receive direct financial benefit from the production and sale of the product.
      (2)   The individual processes eligible for an exemption must be
individually metered and must not have a connection to the sanitary sewer
system.  A drawing, sealed by a professional engineer, showing the piping
configuration, shall be filed with the City.
      (3)   Any discharge to the storm sewer system shall be in accordance with
the rules and regulations of the City, County, and Environmental Protection
Agency.
      (4)   The customer will be required to develop and implement a testing
program.  The customer shall be responsible for all costs associated with the
testing, including the costs incurred by the City in reviewing and observing
the testing program.  The customer will be required to submit a work plan to
the City, prior to implementation.  As part of the testing program, an annual
walk-through inspection shall be performed and physical testing shall be
verified every five years, or more often if there is reason to believe that the
on-site system has deteriorated.
      (5)   Current exempted businesses and industries must apply and comply
within six months to obtain an exemption.
   (c)   Residential Summer Sprinkling Program.  There is hereby established a
residential summer sprinkling program that shall operate in accordance with the
following provisions:
      (1)   Definitions.  Whenever they are used in this subsection, the
meaning of these terms shall be defined as follows:
         A.   “Summer Residential Sprinkling User Charges” (SRSUC) shall mean a
vehicle by which the City shall assess sewer service charges to eligible
residential users defined herein.
         B.   “Summer Billing Period” shall mean the period between May 1 and
September 30 inclusive.
         C.   “Winter Billing Period” shall mean the period between October 1
and April 30 inclusive.
         D.   “Eligible User” shall mean any owner-occupied one-, two-, three-
or four family residences within the City of Wickliffe where sewer service
charges are based upon water consumption.
         E.   “Winter Billing Period Usage” shall mean the calculated daily
consumption during the winter billing period.
      (2)   Summer Residential Sprinkling User Charges.  Upon receipt of a
timely application submitted therefore, the City of Wickliffe shall provide
Summer Sprinkling User Charges to Eligible Users.  These charges shall be
provided by basing the sewer charges during the summer billing period on the
smaller of either the actual water consumption or a calculated consumption
based upon winter billing period usage.
      (3)   Application for Summer Residential Sprinkling User Charges.  An
application for Summer Residential Sprinkling User Charges (SRSUC) must be made
by an Eligible User via the application provided by the City and shall be in
such form and contain such information as required by the City.  The
application, together with a one-time twenty dollar ($20.00) fee must be
submitted to the City by April 30 of any year to be eligible.  The SRSUC will
continue from year to year unless otherwise cancelled according to the
provisions herein.
      (4)   Removal from Summer Residential Sprinkling User Charges.  Upon the
change of ownership of any property or conversion to rental property, that
property’s Summer Residential Sprinkling User Charges will be cancelled.  Any
subsequent Eligible User must submit a new application and a twenty dollar
($20.00) fee.  Additionally, Summer Residential Sprinkling User Charges shall
be cancelled due to errors or falsifications on the application.
      (5)   Establishing Program.  The Mayor is hereby authorized to enter into
an agreement with the Lake County Department of Utilities to create the
necessary software for programming winter averaging and establishing Summer
Residential Sprinkling User Charges.  The Director of Finance is hereby
authorized to pay for such programming from the appropriate fund. At such time
and to the extent that software programming is necessary to apply the
regulations is in place, Eligible Users, may apply to the City of Wickliffe on
applications pursuant to the regulations adopted by the City, which shall have
the full force and effect of an ordinance. 
         (Ord. 2007-06.  Passed 2-12-07.)
   935.04  SEWER CHARGES BILLED WITH WATER CHARGES; COLLECTION FEE.
   The sewer rental charge shall be payable at the same time and place as water
bills for the district in which the premises served are located. The City of
Cleveland is authorized to bill and collect the foregoing charges, in addition
to its established rate for water consumed, and include the same on its regular
water bills. Such sewer service or rental charges, herein provided, shall be
computed quarterly and shall be included as a separate item or charge on each
quarterly water bill. The City of Cleveland shall include on such quarterly
billings, an additional charge of two dollars and twenty-five cents ($2.25) per
billing, per account, for the benefit of the City of Cleveland, which fee the
City of Cleveland shall retain for each billing issued by the City, whether
such bill is collected or not.
(Ord. 1983-12. Passed 2-28-83.)
   935.05  WATER TURNED OFF IF SEWER BILL NOT PAID.
   Failure to pay the sewer service or rental charge by the due date on the
delinquent notice, sent on unpaid water bills, to which were added the sewer
service or rental charges, shall result in termination of water service,
without regard to change of ownership or occupancy of such premises; and water
shall not again be turned on or supplied until all sewer service or rental
charges due and payable shall have been paid and discharged.
(Ord. 1961-2. Passed 2-13-61.)
   935.06  UNPAID CHARGES CERTIFIED TO COUNTY AUDITOR FOR COLLECTION.
   Every sewer service or rental charge which has become due and payable and
has remained unpaid for more than thirty days prior to the first day of July of
each year, shall be certified by the Director of Finance to the County Auditor
on or before the second Monday in September of each year, together with a
pertinent description of the premises to which the sewer service or rental
charge has been made. The amount so certified shall be placed by the Auditor on
the tax duplicate of the County to be collected as other taxes are collected.
In addition to such collection procedure, any such unpaid amount may be
collected through civil action brought in the name of the City in any court of
competent civil jurisdiction.
(Ord. 1961-2. Passed 2-13-61.)
   935.07  REGULATIONS MAY BE ADOPTED.
   The Mayor or Director of Public Service shall make and enforce such bylaws
and regulations as he may believe necessary for the collection of sewer service
or rental charges and for the safe, economical and efficient management and
protection of the City sewerage system. Such bylaws and regulations, when
published by posting, as required for ordinances after passage, shall have the
same force and effect as ordinances of the City when not repugnant thereto or
to the Constitution or laws of the State of Ohio.
(Ord. 1961-2. Passed 2-13-61.)
   935.08  SEWER RENTAL FUND.
   Moneys received from the collection of the sewer service or rental charge
authorized by this chapter shall be deposited weekly with the Director of
Finance, who shall keep a separate and distinct fund and account to be known as
the Sewer Rental Fund. When appropriated by Council, such Fund shall be
available for the payment of the cost and expense of the management,
maintenance, operation, testing, cleaning, enlargement, replacement and
extension of the sewerage system to unsewered areas, and reconstruction and
repair of the sewerage system and/or the construction and reconstruction of
sewage pumping treatment and disposal works, pursuant to the statutes and/or
Constitution of the State of Ohio providing for the distribution of funds
derived from sewer rentals.
(Ord. 1961-2. Passed 2-13-61.)
   935.09  BUILDING MUST USE AVAILABLE SEWERS.
   (a)    Buildings with Plumbing Fixtures Must Be Equipped with Drainage
System. Every building or other structure or premises in or on which plumbing
fixtures are installed, or in or on which liquid or water-borne wastes
accumulate, shall be equipped with an approved drainage and plumbing system to
convey all liquid or water-borne wastes to a public sanitary or storm sewer;
except that where a public sewer is not available, other approved provisions
shall be made for disposing of such wastes in conformity with the provisions of
other applicable laws, ordinances, rules or regulations.
   (b)    Storm Water Drainage. Roofs, paved areas, yards, courts, open shafts
and every open excavation or part of a lot or premises where water accumulates
or stands, shall be drained into a storm sewer system, but if such storm sewer
is not available, they shall be drained to an approved receptacle or conducted
to a point of disposal approved by the Building Commissioner.
   (c)    Water Supply System. All buildings or other structures or premises
equipped with plumbing fixtures shall have provisions for supplying such
fixtures with an adequate supply of water.
(Ord. 1960-31. Passed 4-11-60.)
   935.10  MANDATORY SEWER CONNECTIONS FOR DWELLINGS.
   Any owner or owners, person or persons, having control of any building which
is used as a dwelling house or for living purposes or which is regularly
inhabited or used by any person or persons, the lot of which abuts on a
sanitary sewer or to which a sanitary sewer is accessible and which has
sanitary plumbing installed but which drains into any cesspool, drain, ditch or
other place, shall disconnect the plumbing therefrom and make proper connection
with the City sanitary sewer system.
(Ord. 1937-4. Passed 4-28-37.)
   935.11  PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS.
   The owner of any lot or lands within the City upon which there is any
structure used for human habitation and for which sanitary sewer facilities are
not available shall, within sixty days from notice from the County Department
of Health, install, erect or construct a septic tank of sufficient capacity in
accordance with the rules, regulations and sanitary code of the Department of
Health.
(Ord. 1941-11. Passed 6-25-41.)
   935.12  INFORMATION FOR BUILDING PERMIT.
   Every person applying for a building permit for the construction of any
structure designed or to be used for human habitation upon any lot or land for
which sanitary sewer facilities are not available shall state on the
application the type of construction, size, capacity and location of any septic
tank. Failure to include the information on the application shall be cause for
refusal of a building permit by the Building Commissioner. Upon the application
being so filed the Commissioner shall give notice to the County Department of
Health, of the proposed construction of the septic tank and request and obtain
an inspection and approval thereof by the proper officer before issuing any
certificate of completion to the owner, contractor, or agent of either.
(Ord. 1941-11. Passed 6-25-41.)
   935.13  PHOTOGRAPHS OR VISUAL INSPECTION OF SEWERS.
   (a)    The Director of Public Service shall, prior to final approval of any
newly installed sewer system and/or reconstructed sewer, require that any and
all contractors cause photographs to be made of the entire sewer system
installed, showing thereby that the sewer system has been constructed upon
sound engineering basis and that the sewer system is free of any and all
accumulations of foreign substance and nature and that the passage and flow of
sewage and storm water is free and clear. If, in the discretion of the
Director, the sewers are large enough for a visual inspection to be made, in
lieu of photographs, such a visual inspection shall be made and a report of
such inspection submitted to the City,
   (b)    Upon inspection of such photographs and/or visual inspection reports
and, if satisfied that such sewer is free and clear of all foreign substance
and there is nothing present to prevent free flow of sewage and storm waters,
the Director is hereby authorized to approve same as a final inspection,
placing in safekeeping all photographs and/or inspection records for future
reference by the City.
   (c)    The cost of such photographing and photographs and/or inspection
reports shall be entirely paid for by the contractor or developer of such land
and/or sewer system, and such photographs and/or inspection reports shall
remain the property of the City.
(Ord. 1965-83. Passed 10-11-65.)
   935.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00).

   939.01  SPRINKLING RESTRICTION.
   Whenever the Mayor declares that an emergency exists resulting from
inadequate water supply for human consumption and sanitary purposes, no person
shall use any water furnished through the water mains in the City for the
purpose of sprinkling or watering lawns, gardens, streets or other grounds, nor
shall any person, during this period permit the use of water for this purpose
from the service pipes connected with the water mains of the City.
(Ord. 1948-11. Passed 2-9-48.)
   939.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00).

      Littering and deposits of refuse - see GEN. OFF.

      Criminal trespass - see GEN. OFF.

      Destruction of shrubs or trees - see GEN. OFF.

      Fireworks display permits - see GEN. OFF.
549.11
   951.01  USE OF PARKS; REFRESHMENTS; IDENTIFICATION CARDS.
   (a)    Parks in this City are constructed and maintained for the use of the
public at large, and shall be open daily to all residents on absolutely equal
terms and none shall be given special privileges therein, or be permitted to
make use of them for any purpose not practically common to all and in
consonance with the proper use of the park.
(Ord. 1956-11.  Passed 10-22-56.)
   (b)    The City reserves the exclusive right and privilege to sell or cause
to be sold any food, souvenirs or refreshments, other than those containing
alcohol, in any of its parks.  This subsection (b) hereof, shall not apply to
the holder of a Special Event Permit obtained in compliance with Section
1327.01(d) hereof.  Upon appropriate action of Council and only after
competitive bidding, the City may award concession contracts for the sale of
food, souvenirs or refreshments.  (Ord. 2018-27.  Passed 6-25-18.)
   (c)    Attended recreational facilities within parks in the City shall be
available to residents of the City at no charge upon the presentation of
identification cards which shall be provided to residents by the Recreation
Director upon the presentation of suitable identification for a fee of one
dollar ($1.00). Recreational facilities shall be available to nonresidents upon
the payment of a user's fee to be determined by the Director. A schedule of
such fees shall be posted at each recreational facility.
(Ord. 1986-24. Passed 6-9-86.)
   951.02  COMMERCIAL VEHICLES IN PARKS.
   Heavily laden vehicles or vehicles carrying or ordinarily used in carrying
merchandise, goods, tools, material or rubbish, market wagons, milk wagons,
dirt carts, moving vans, drays or trucks, except such as may be used in the
park service or such as may be authorized, in writing by the Director of Public
Service or his nominee, are prohibited from passing over the driveways in any
of the parks. The Director of Public Service or his nominee may grant
permission for vehicles carrying passengers only, and vehicles carrying
materials to buildings on the parkways and adjacent thereto to use park
roadways when no other driveways or roadways are accessible or passable, if
found necessary.
   Nothing contained in this section shall be held or construed to prohibit the
established right of travel or occupancy of any of the public streets or
avenues running through or around any of the parks.
(Ord. 1956-11. Passed 10-22-56.)
   951.03  REMOVAL OR DESTRUCTION OF PROPERTY.
   No person shall remove, destroy, break, injure, mutilate or deface in any
way any structure, monument, statue, vase, fountain, table, bench, wall, fence,
railing, vehicle, flower, building or other structure or property in any park
or parkway, and no person, other than an employee of the parks, shall bring
into any of the parks, or have in his possession while therein, any tree, shrub
or plant or any newly plucked branch or leaf of a tree, shrub or plant, except
with the written permission of the Director of Public Service.
(Ord. 1956-11. Passed 10-22-56.)
   951.04  PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS.
   Solicitors, agents, fakirs, peddlers, mendicants, strolling musicians, organ
grinders, exhorters and showmen are prohibited from plying their several
vocations within the park limits.
(Ord. 1956-11. Passed 10-22-56.)
   951.05  DISORDERLY CONDUCT.
   Sleeping or protracted lounging on the seats of benches, loud, boisterous,
threatening or abusive, insulting or indecent language, or disorderly conduct
or behavior or any act tending to be a breach of public peace is prohibited.
(Ord. 1956-11. Passed 10-22-56.)
   951.06  PERMITS SUBJECT TO RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   All permits issued by the Director of Public Service shall be subject to the
park rules and regulations and City ordinances, and persons to whom the permits
are issued shall be bound by the rules, regulations and ordinances, as fully as
though the same were inserted in the permits, except if the permit provides
otherwise.
(Ord. 1956-11. Passed 10-22-56.)
   951.07  PARKING WINDSHIELD STICKER; NONRESIDENT PARKING FEE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former Section
951.07 was repealed by Ordinance 2009-33.)
   951.08  PROHIBITED CONDUCT.
   No person, while on the grounds of any City park shall:
   (a)   Commit any disorderly or immoral act, appear in improper dress, utter
loud or indecent language, or conduct himself in a noisy, boisterous, rude,
insulting or other manner by either word or act toward any other person.
   (b)   Be allowed to enter or remain in, or be found in, an intoxicated
condition in a park.
   (c)   Take into a park any intoxicating liquor or alcoholic beverage either
for sale to others or for his or her own use or the use of others; sell, give
away, or dispose of any intoxicating liquor or alcoholic beverage.  This
subsection (c) hereof, shall not apply to the holder of a Special Event Permit
obtained in compliance with Section
1327.01(d) hereof.
   (d)   Have any intoxicating liquor or alcoholic beverage in his or her
possession.  This subsection (d) hereof, shall not apply to a person attending
a Special Event and the intoxicating liquor or alcoholic beverage in his or her
possession was obtained from the holder of a Special Event Permit in compliance
with Section
1327.01(d) hereof.
   (e)   Throw stones, sticks, cans or bottles, or play golf or hit golf balls,
or throw or hit any other dangerous object.
   (f)   Throw or cause to be thrown any object on any ice skating pond or
pond.
   (g)   Write, paint, carve or deface in any manner any tree, bench or
structure, or injure any tree, plant, grass, flower or structure.
   (h)   Gamble or play any game of chance.
   (i)   Publicly solicit subscriptions or beg.
   (j)   Wash, clean or polish any automobile or other vehicle.
   (k)   Throw or leave any refuse or garbage in any other place than in the
receptacles provided therefor.
   (l)   Ride or drive any vehicle at a rate of speed exceeding fifteen miles
per hour.
   (m)   Fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of any
public officer.
   (n)   Drive or ride a motorcycle, mini-bike, snowmobile or any other motor-
driven vehicle.
   (o)   Tie a horse to a tree.
   (p)   Climb any tree or walk, stand or sit upon any monument, vase,
fountain, railing or fence.
   (q)   Sound any whistle.
   (r)   Injure, deface or destroy any notice of the rules and regulations
governing the parks which have been posted or permanently fixed by order or
permission of the Director of Public Service.
      (Ord. 2018-28.  Passed 6-25-18.)
   951.09  ACTS REQUIRING DIRECTOR’S PRIOR APPROVAL.
   No person or organization while on the grounds of any City park, unless
prior permission has been obtained from the Director of Public Service or his
designee, shall:
   (a)   Post or display any sign, banner or advertisement, or offer anything
for sale.
   (b)   Hold any public meeting or gathering or engage in any marching or
driving as a member of a military, political or other organization, or deliver
any public speech, or use a speaker’s rostrum or stand.
   (c)   Obstruct in any way any roadway or path, enter or leave City parks
except at the established exits and entrances, or park any vehicle after
sundown or before sunup, except when using park facilities in accordance with
regulations governing the use of such facilities.
   (d)   Discharge any firearms or fireworks, or ignite or burn any sparkler.
   (e)   Hold any picnic at a place not designated for that purpose, or play
baseball or any other game at a place not designated for that purpose.
   (f)   Enter any place where a no admittance sign has been posted.
   (g)   Build any fire, except at places provided for that purpose.
   (h)   Carry any shrub, flower, firearm, slingshot, axe, saw, shovel or spade
into such park.  (Ord. 1964-62.  Passed 7-13-64.)
   (i)   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former subsection (i) was repealed by Ordinance 2008-
08.)
   (j)   Hold, conduct or present any musical, theatrical or other
entertainment.
   (k)   Be in a parade or procession.
   (l)   Distribute any circular, handbill, card or other written or printed
matter.
      (Ord.  1956-11.  Passed 10-22-56.)
 
   951.10  CLOSING HOURS.
   All City parks shall be open during such hours as may be determined by the
Safety Director and Director of Public Service.  Notice of the opening and
closing hours shall be conspicuously posted at the entrances of each City park
and no person shall remain within the parks while closed unless given specific
written permission by the Director of Public Service.
(Ord. 2005-88.  Passed 12-12-05.)
   951.11  RENAMING CERTAIN PARKS.
   (a)   The present recreational park now known as Twin Lakes Park is hereby
renamed and shall be known as Louis R. Orlando Park.
(Ord. 1978-84.  Passed 11-13-78.)
   (b)   The present recreational park now known as Ridgewick Park is hereby
renamed and shall be known as Fielding Featherston III Park.
(Ord. 1978-85.  Passed 11-13-78.)
   (c)   The recreational park presently known as Civic Park is hereby renamed
and shall be known as Levi Lane Park. 
(Ord. 2000-47.  Passed 11-13-00.)
   951.12  ANIMAL CONTROL.
   (a)   No person shall bring, have, keep, or leave any animal in the park
areas of the City, except dogs, which shall be restrained by a leash in such a
manner as to be under a person’s control at all times.  Dogs will only be
permitted in the park areas designated as a park walkway, path or sidewalk.
 
   (b)   The owner or person in control of any dog shall dispose of any fecal
matter left by his/her dog.
 
   (c)   No person shall permit any dog to run at large.
(Ord. 2008-08.  Passed 4-14-08.)
   951.13  PROTECTION OF ANIMALS; HUNTING AND FISHING.
   (a)   No person shall hunt, capture, take, trap or in any other way abuse,
molest, injure, pursue or destroy any animal, other than by fishing, without a
permit from the Director of Public Service or his/her designee.
 
   (b)   No person shall move, injure, or destroy any bird nest, egg, or any
animal habitation.
 
   (c)   No person shall fish in park ponds in violation of any sign or signs
prohibiting fishing or a manner thereof.
(Ord. 2008-08. Passed 4-14-08.)
   951.14   PARKING.
   Motor vehicles, motorbikes, bicycles and other vehicles of any nature shall
be parked in such areas and in such a manner as designated by signs, posters,
or verbal orders.  Any such vehicle stopped or parked in violation hereof may
be removed or towed away upon order of any police officer.  (Ord. 2008-08. 
Passed 4-14-08.)
   951.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
(Ord. 2005-88.  Passed 12-12-05.)
CHAPTER 953
Municipal Facilities
953.01   Definitions.
953.02   Hours and curfew.
953.03   Sale and consumption of liquor, wine and beer  prohibited.
953.04   Use and rental.
953.05   Priorities.
953.06   Application review.
953.07   Schedule of charges.
953.08   Terms and conditions.
953.09   Reserved.
953.10   Application and indemnification.
953.11   Security requirements.
953.12   Rules and regulations.
953.13   Rental for Monte Carlo casino nights or bingo events.
953.99   Penalty.
   953.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Adult groups" means groups composed principally of members above the
age of eighteen.
   (b)   "City Park" shall mean Coulby Park, Featherston Park, Intihar Park,
Jindra Park, Levi Lane Park, Nehls Park, and Orlando Park.
   (c)   "Engagement" means any activity, including meetings.
   (d)   “Governmental units" means state, local and municipal entities,
departments, agencies, boards, commissions and officials in the conduct of
governmental business.
   (e)   "Meeting" means an assembly for the sole purpose of conducting
business. The Director of Recreation is hereby authorized to determine whether
or not proposed engagements qualify as meetings within the definition set forth
here.
   (f)   "Multiple engagements" means two or more engagements requested by the
same applicant on a single application.
   (g)   "Municipal facility" shall mean and include the Wickliffe Community/
Senior Center and Wickliffe City Hall.
   (h)   "Nonresident" means, with respect to an individual, an applicant who
does not live in the City or an applicant who, although living in the City, is
renting the Wickliffe Community/Senior Center principally for the benefit and
use of an individual or individuals who do not live in the City and, with
respect to a group or organization, an applicant group or organization whose
membership is principally composed of individuals who do not live in the City.
   (i)   "Resident" means, with respect to an individual, an applicant who
lives in the City and, with respect to a group or organization whose membership
is principally composed of individuals who live in the City.
   (j)   "Sanctioned and/or affiliated organization" means a group or
organization registered with the Wickliffe Recreation Department pursuant to
and in compliance with the requirements for affiliation established by the
Wickliffe Recreation Commission.
   (k)   "Youth groups" means groups principally composed of members under the
age of eighteen and which are registered affiliates of the Wickliffe Recreation
Commission.
   (l)   "Weekend" means from 5:00 p.m. on Friday until 12:00 midnight on
Sunday.
      (Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.02   HOURS AND CURFEW.
   (a)   No person shall loiter, idle, wander, stroll, play or otherwise be
present in or upon any municipal facility from dusk to dawn of the following
day. Further, the provisions of this section shall not apply to such person
when attending, going to or coming from a function in a City park, for which a
permit has been issued by or on behalf of the City or for which function
permission has been granted by the Recreation Director of the City.
   (b)   No person shall loiter, idle, wander, stroll, play or otherwise be
present in or upon any municipal facility in violation of the provisions of
subsection (a) hereof, provided, however, that the provisions of this section
shall not apply to a person attending, going to or coming from a function in a
municipal facility, for which function a permit has been issued by or on behalf
of the City or permission has been granted by the City Recreation Director,
provided that such permitted or authorized functions must be completed or
terminated by 12:00 midnight.
   (c)   No parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody
of a person under the age of eighteen years shall knowingly permit such person
under the age of eighteen years to loiter, idle, wander, stroll, play or
otherwise be present in or upon, any municipal facility in violation of the
provisions of this section.
(Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.03  SALE AND CONSUMPTION OF LIQUOR, WINE AND BEER PROHIBITED.
   Unless otherwise authorized by the City Charter, an ordinance or a
resolution of Council, no person shall sell, offer for sale, furnish, give
away, consume or have in his or her possession liquor, wine or beer in or upon
any municipal facility.
(Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.04  USE AND RENTAL.
   The Recreation Director is hereby authorized to permit the use and rental of
municipal facilities, upon written application therefore in such form as is
prescribed by him or her, upon the terms and conditions and subject to charges
hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.05  PRIORITIES.
   Permits for the use and rental of municipal facilities shall be issued to
the person or organization on such day. However, any application may be denied
and a permit refused when the facilities are required by Council or any other
officer, official group, organization or committee of the City for any City
sponsored activity on the day or portion thereof for which use and rental are
sought unless a contract has been signed.
(Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.06   APPLICATION REVIEW.
   The following provisions shall govern the consideration and approval of
applications for the rental or use of municipal facilities:
   (a)   Applications shall be considered by the Recreation Director.
   (b)   An application shall be acted upon within thirty days of its receipt
by the Recreation Director.
      (Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.07   SCHEDULE OF CHARGES.
   All fees, costs or expenses that shall be charged for the use and/or rental
of a municipal facility shall be approved annually by Council upon the
recommendation of the Recreation Director, and a schedule of same shall be
available to the public from the office of the Recreation Director.  (Ord.
2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.08   TERMS AND CONDITIONS.
   The use and/or rental of municipal facilities shall be subject to the
following terms and conditions:
   (a)   Damage Deposit. In addition to any fee, cost or expense to be charged
for the use of a municipal facility, a damage deposit, in an amount that has
been determined by Council upon the recommendation of the Recreation Director,
must accompany all applications. Such deposits shall be applied by the City to
pay the costs of repairing or replacing any damage to or destruction of the
premises or any personal property therein occurring and the balance of such
deposit shall thereupon be returned to the applicant. However, where the
Service Director determines that an excessive clean-up of facilities is
required, as a result of an engagement, a sum shall be charged against such
deposit to cover the cost of such clean-up. The applicant shall be liable for
any and all expense and/or damage, even where the clean-up and damage expense
exceed the damage deposit. The damage deposit provided for herein may be waived
by the Recreation Director.
   (b)   Payment.The applicable charge for the use and rental shall be paid in
advance. No engagement shall be secured until payment is received. For multiple
engagement bookings, all bookings to be included in the application shall be
paid in advance unless waived by the Director of Recreation. No application
shall be considered processed or finalized until payment is received. The
Recreation Director is also authorized to waive fees as described in this
chapter. All applications are considered "first come, first served." Payment
and application procedures shall be completed at least two weeks before the
scheduled engagement. Consideration in special cases on emergency basis will be
considered by the Recreation Director.
   (c)   Cancellation and Refunds. In the event an engagement is cancelled, the
damage deposit shall be refunded; and further, rental payments shall be
refunded in accordance with a schedule that shall be established by Council
upon the recommendation of the Recreation Director.
      (Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.09  RESERVED.
   953.10   APPLICATION AND INDEMNIFICATION.
   The application for a permit for the use and rental of a municipal facility
shall be signed either by the individual seeking such use and rental for
private purposes, or, in the case of an organization, by a duly authorized
officer of record, on file in the Recreation Director's office. The
applications shall disclose the estimated number of persons to be present and
shall specify the hours during which the premises will be used. As a part of
such application, the applicant shall agree to indemnify the City and hold it
harmless from any liability resulting from the use of such premises by the
applicant, his or her guests, members of any organization or any other person
entering the premises of the subject municipal facility during the time of such
an engagement, including any liability arising by virtue of the violation by
any person of any provisions of the laws of the State relating to alcoholic
beverages.
(Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.11  SECURITY REQUIREMENTS.
   The Recreation Director may require, as a condition for the issuance of a
permit for any engagement for the use of a municipal facility, that a certain
number of police officers employed by the City be hired by the applicant to be
present during the hours specified by the Recreation Director and such shall be
paid at the prevailing rate applicable in the City.
(Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.12   RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Recreation Department is hereby authorized and directed to prepare rules
and regulations relating to the use and rental of the facilities of the
municipal facility in order to carry into effect the provisions of this chapter
and to prescribe forms of applications and permits for use by the City. Such
rules and regulations shall be a part of the contract and posted in a
conspicuous place within the premises.
(Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.13  RENTAL FOR MONTE CARLO CASINO NIGHTS OR BINGO EVENTS.
   (a)   Any municipal facility may be rented for a Monte Carlo casino night or
bingo-like event by an organization that meets the following criteria:
      (1)   The organization must be an affiliated organization or sanctioned
organization as defined by Chapter
149 of the Administrative Code, or a nonprofit organization physically located
within the City boundaries.
      (2)   The organization must have a current Section 501(c)(3) exemption
filed with the Recreation Director at the time an application for rental is
submitted.
      (3)   The event must be in compliance with all applicable laws governing
charitable gambling events pursuant to City of Wickliffe Codified Ordinances of
Chapter
517, entitled “Gambling” and Ohio Revised Code Chapter 2915, entitled,
“Gambling”.
      (4)   The organization must be staffed at the event only by non-paid
volunteers.
   (b)   Any organization will be denied future use of the building for any
misrepresentation or failure to comply with any provision set forth in
subsection (a) hereof.
   (c)   The Recreation Director may deny an application under subsection (a)
hereof if an organization does not meet the criteria provided for under said
subsection. Any denial may be appealed to the Mayor by filing a written notice
of appeal with the Finance Director within five days of the denial of the
application.
(Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
   953.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be subject to temporary or permanent
suspension from any further use or rental of a municipal facility.
(Ord. 2008-17.  Passed 4-28-08.)
CHAPTER 955
Municipal Swimming Pools
955.01   Trespassing upon fenced-in area.
955.02   Pool season and hours.
955.03   Aquatic pass fees.
955.04   Members of armed forces admitted free.
955.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Criminal trespass - see GEN. OFF.
541.05
   955.01  TRESPASSING UPON FENCED-IN AREA.
   No person shall enter or trespass upon the premises of the fenced-in areas
of the City swimming pools and the City spray park.
(Ord. 2013-06.  Passed 3-25-13.)
   955.02  POOL SEASON AND HOURS.
   (a)   City swimming pools and spray park shall be open from June until Labor
Day of each year.  The exact dates and hours of operation will be recommended
annually by the Director of Recreation with approval of the Mayor and Council.
 
   (b)   Hours for swimming instruction, general open swimming, and private
splash parties will be recommended annually by the Director of Recreation with
approval of the Mayor and Council.  (Ord. 2013-06.  Passed 3-25-13.)
   955.03  AQUATIC PASS FEES.
   (a)   Annually, the Director of Recreation shall establish the aquatic pass
fees that will be charged for residential families’ use of the City swimming
pools and the City spray park.  Said annual aquatic pass fees shall be approved
by the Mayor and Council and shall be published and posted.  Residents must
present a valid aquatic pass upon each visit to gain admittance to the City’s
pool facilities and spray park facility.
 
   (b)   For the purpose of this chapter, proof of residency shall include a
current driver’s license and a current (i.e. within 90 days) utility bill, as
well as birth certificates for each child.
 
   (c)   For the purpose of this chapter, a “residential family” shall include
the adult head of household and his/her spouse or partner and the dependent
children living in that household who are 20 years of age and under.  In the
absence of a marriage license, residency of partner must be established.  (Ord.
2013-06.  Passed 3-25-13.)
   955.04  MEMBERS OF ARMED FORCES ADMITTED FREE.
   Notwithstanding any other provisions of these Codified Ordinances, any
resident of the City who is a member of the armed forces of the United States
of America and who is currently serving at some military establishment outside
of Lake or Geauga County is hereby granted the privilege of free admission to
the City pools.   
(Ord. 2013-06.  Passed 3-25-13.)
   955.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Section
955.01 is guilty of criminal trespass, a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and
shall be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and serve a
jail term of not more than thirty (30) days or both.
(Ord. 2013-06.  Passed 3-25-13.)
