CHAPTER 961
Garbage, Rubbish and Refuse Collection
961.01    Definitions.
961.02   Collection supervised by Director of Public Service.
961.03   Garbage, rubbish and refuse collection.
961.04   Container requirements.
961.05   Placement and maintenance of containers.
961.06   Placement of containers for curb service pickup.
961.07   Scavenging prohibited.
961.08   Rules and regulations.
961.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Collection and disposal of garbage - see Ohio R.C. 715.43, 717.01
      Disposal and transportation upon public ways - see Ohio R.C. 3767.20 et
seq.
      Vehicle loads dropping, sifting, leaking - see TRAF.
339.08
      Littering- see GEN. OFF.
521.08
      Solid waste container restrictions - see GEN. OFF.
521.13
      Sanitary landfill - see S.U.&P.S. Ch.
959
   961.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in
the plural number include the singular number and words in the singular number
include the plural number. "Shall" is always mandatory and not merely
directory.
   (a)     "Ashes" means the residue of the combustion of any type of solid
fuel such as wood, coke, charcoal and like substances.
   (b)     "Brush" means tree trimmings too large to containerize including
branches not over four inches in diameter and sixty inches in length.
   (c)     "Building or construction waste" means waste materials and rubbish
resulting from the construction, alteration or repair of buildings and
structures such as walls, driveways, sidewalks and the like. Building or
construction waste may consist of wood, plaster, metal, cement, lime, brick,
mortar, concrete, lathing, roofing, earth, stone, slag, cinders and structural
material.
   (d)     "Bulk items" means nonrefrigerant appliances, furniture, mattresses
and carpets.
   (e)     "Contractor" means the current holder of the contract with the City
for the collection and disposal of refuse and/or recyclable materials.
   (f)     "Dead animals" means the carcasses of dogs, cats, horses, and all
dead animals of like size as distinguished from the carcasses of birds, small
animals, rats and mice.
   (g)    "Garbage" means putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from
the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food.
   (h)     "Industrial wastes" means wastes that result from manufacturing,
industrial and wholesale businesses.
   (i)     "Multiple family residence or apartment" includes the grouping
together under a common roof or on a single lot of three or more residential
units.
   (j)     "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
   (k)     "Reasonable accumulation" means the amount of refuse determined by
the Director to be considered within reason during a collection period for the
standard charge.
   (l)     "Refrigerant item" means any appliance containing a chemical
refrigerant, including air conditioners, dehumidifiers, refrigerators and
freezers.
   (m)     "Refuse" includes all solid waste, except body waste, including
garbage, rubbish, ashes and street cleanings.
   (n)    “Rubbish” includes household, commercial, and institutional
combustible and noncombustible solid waste material, but not limited to paper,
textiles, glass, metal, ashes, grass, and hedge and tree trimmings.
   (o)    "Unacceptable refuse" means automotive vehicle parts, tires, land
clearing residue (stumps, logs, etc.), animal excrement and dead animals,
building and construction waste, earth, large rocks, commercial waste and
industrial waste, hazardous waste or any refuse not properly bagged,
containerized or bundled.
      (Ord. 2008-13.  Passed 5-12-08.)
   961.02  COLLECTION SUPERVISED BY DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SERVICE.
   (a)   All garbage, rubbish, and refuse accumulated in the City shall be
collected, conveyed, and disposed of either by the contractor or under special
circumstances by the City, under the supervision of the Director of Public
Service.  The Director of Public Service shall have the authority to make
regulations concerning the days of collection, type and location of waste
containers, and such other matters pertaining to the collection, conveyance,
and disposal as he/she finds necessary; and to change and modify the same after
notice as required by law, provided that such regulations are not contrary to
the current contract and/or the provisions hereof.  Waste of the categories
listed as “unacceptable refuse” shall not be collected, except under special
circumstances as determined by the Director of Public Service.
(Ord. 2008-13.  Passed 5-12-08.)
 
   (b)   The Director of Public Service shall make and enforce such orders,
rules and regulations as may be necessary for the proper cost, collection, and
disposal of garbage, rubbish, and refuse.  The cost for the collection and
disposal of garbage, rubbish and refuse shall be negotiated by the Director of
Public Service and shall be approved by the Mayor and the Council of the City. 

(Ord. 2014-41.  Passed 11-10-14.)
   961.03  GARBAGE, RUBBISH, AND REFUSE COLLECTION.
   (a)   The City of Wickliffe provides curb service to the residents of one-,
two-, and three-family freestanding residential units.  Curb service includes a
weekly collection of household garbage and rubbish. 
   (b)   Collection of garbage and rubbish from condominiums does not provide
or allow curb service.
   (c)     Collection of garbage and rubbish from three or more unit multiple-
family residential, commercial, industrial, institutional, or nonprofit
locations shall be by private haulers.
(Ord. 2008-13.  Passed 5-12-08.)
   961.04  CONTAINER REQUIREMENTS.
   No person of any public or private premise shall permit the accumulation
upon the premise of any garbage or rubbish except in covered containers
approved by the Director of Public Service.  Such containers shall be
constructed in such manner as to be strong, not easily corrodible, rodent-
proof, and a capacity of not more than 32 gallons or weighing more than 60
pounds loaded, or in dumpster containers approved by the Director of Public
Service capable of being lifted mechanically by the waste contractor.  All
containers shall have tight covers, the same to be in place at all times except
when garbage or refuse is being deposited or removed.  Odd articles shall be
crushed and/or bundled in lengths not to exceed three feet or 50 pounds in
weight.
(Ord. 2008-13.  Passed 5-12-08.)
   961.05  PLACEMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF CONTAINERS.
   (a)   No garbage, rubbish, or refuse materials shall be collected by the
waste contractor unless the items are placed, maintained, and accumulated as
designated by the Director of Public Service.
   (b)   Every occupant of a dwelling shall dispose of all garbage, rubbish, or
refuse in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in approved leak proof,
nonabsorbent, covered garbage storage receptacles.  The garbage, rubbish, and
refuse receptacles described above shall not be stored on the exterior of a
parcel of land at the following locations:
      (1)   In the front yard of a parcel of land extending from the front wall
of a dwelling structure to the front right-of-way property line across the full
width of the lot.
      (2)   In the front yard of an accessory building extending from the front
wall of the accessory building to the front wall line of the dwelling structure
extending from the side wall of the dwelling structure to the full width of the
side yard where a driveway is located, provided the front wall of the accessory
building is located within twenty feet from the rear wall of the dwelling
structure.
   (c)       Every condominium owner, operator, agent, or association shall be
responsible for providing and maintaining dumpster containers approved by the
Director of Public Service, capable of being lifted mechanically.  Any dumpster
container that does not conform to the provisions approved by the Director of
Public Service or that is insufficient in size to completely accommodate the
garbage, rubbish, and refuse generated from the premises shall be replaced
within seven days of written notification by the Director of Public Service. 
Storage of the dumpster containers shall be behind the rear building line of
the premises.
(Ord. 2008-13.  Passed 5-12-08.)
   961.06  PLACEMENT OF CONTAINERS FOR CURB SERVICE PICKUP.
   All garbage, rubbish, and trash containers shall be placed on the curb at
the tree lawn no sooner than 4:30p.m. on the day prior to the scheduled
garbage, rubbish, and trash collection and removed no later than 9:00p.m. on
the day of such collection.
(Ord. 2008-13.  Passed 5-12-08.)
   961.07  SCAVENGING PROHIBITED.
   No person shall remove, burn, overturn, or tamper with any rubbish, garbage,
or the container therefor, when such rubbish, garbage, or container is set out
on the public street or highway, sidewalk, alley, or on private premises and
when such rubbish, garbage, or container is placed there for the purpose of
collection.  This provision shall not apply to any employee of the Department
of Public Service or any of its duly authorized agents or any state, local, or
federal police agency or to a private person or organization authorized to
remove such rubbish, garbage, or container.  (Ord. 2008-13.  Passed 5-12-08.)
   961.08  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Director of Public Service shall have the authority to make such other
reasonable regulations concerning garbage, rubbish, and refuse collection and
disposal as he/she finds necessary.  (Ord. 2008-13.  Passed 5-12-08.)
   961.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter or any order, rule,
or regulation of the Director of Public Service or his designee, made pursuant
to this chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree and each
day’s continued violation shall constitute a separate offense.  (Ord. 2008-13. 
Passed 5-12-08.)
CHAPTER 963
Cemetery
963.01   Board of Cemetery Trustees; members, terms and actions.
963.02   Services and administration.
963.021   Indigent cremation.
963.03   Fees.
963.04   Planting and decorating of graves and lots, columbarium niches and
scattering gardens.
963.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Burials may be prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 759.05
         Management and control - see Ohio R.C. 759.09
         Burial permits - see Ohio R.C. 3705.24 et seq.
         Burial of indigent persons - see Ohio R.C. 5113.15
   963.01  BOARD OF CEMETERY TRUSTEES; MEMBERS, TERMS AND ACTIONS.
   (a)   The Board of Cemetery Trustees shall consist of six electors of the
City of Wickliffe who shall be appointed by the Mayor, said appointment subject
to a majority of Council, and one member of Council to be selected by Council
for such term as Council shall determine.
   (b)    Such members who are electors of the City of Wickliffe shall be
appointed to serve a term of four years. Vacancies shall be filled for
unexpired terms.
   (c)    After each meeting of the Board of Cemetery Trustees, the Board shall
submit a written report to Council of the actions taken at that meeting.
(Ord. 2007-86.  Passed 1-14-08.)
   963.02  SERVICES AND ADMINISTRATION.
   (a)    The Department of Public Service shall provide services for grave,
columbarium and scattering garden maintenance.
   (b)    The Board of Cemetery Trustees shall adopt rules and regulations,
subject to approval by Council, for administration of the cemetery.
   (c)    The placing and maintaining of headstones, monuments, columbarium
niches and scattering garden plaque shall be in accordance with the fees and
regulations determined by the Board.
   (d)    As required, the Board shall present operating budgets to be approved
by Council, covering its operation of the City Cemetery.
   (e)    The Director of Finance shall maintain a separate account covering
operation of the City Cemetery and shall act as the agent of the Board and
account for all funds received, disbursed or transferred.
   (f)   The Director of Finance shall record in a book provided for that
purpose, a plat of all grounds for cemetery purposes and a directory of all
contracts for the cemetery columbarium niches.  The conveyance or contract
shall, at the expense of the person receiving it, be recorded by the Director
of Finance in a book kept for that purpose.
(Ord. 2007-81.  Passed 12-10-07.)
   (g)   On the Wickliffe Cemetery grounds is a special garden for people
interested in scattering the cremated remains of their loved ones.  Included is
a memorializing plaque in the scattering garden bearing an inscription of the
name of the deceased, their date of birth, and date of death.  The Director of
Finance shall record in a book for that purpose a directory of all contracts
for the scattering garden.
   (h)   Fees and rules and regulations have been promulgated by the Board of
Cemetery Trustees pursuant to this section.  Copies of the cemetery rules and
regulations are available at Wickliffe City Hall, Department of Public Service.
(Ord. 2011-50.  Passed 9-12-11.)
   963.021 INDIGENT CREMATION.
   (a)   An indigent person means a person or persons whose income is at the
current poverty threshold established by the United States Office of Management
and Budget (§120.51(B), Ohio Revised Code).  The determination of indigency
shall be in the manner provided by Section 120.05 of the Ohio Revised Code.
   (b)   When the body of a dead person is found in the City of Wickliffe and
such person was not an inmate of a correctional, benevolent or charitable
institution of this state, and the body is not claimed by any person for
private interment or cremation at the person’s own expense, or delivered for
the purpose of medical or surgical study or dissection in accordance with
Section 1713.34 of the Ohio Revised Code, it shall be disposed of as follows:
      (1)   If the decedent was a legal resident of the City of Wickliffe and
the decedent is indigent as defined by Section 120.51(B), Ohio Revised Code,
the proper officers of the City in which the decedent’s body was found shall
cause the body to be cremated at the expense of the City of Wickliffe.  Such
officers shall cause the decedent’s cremated remains to be scattered in the
Wickliffe Cemetery scattering garden.  The name of the indigent deceased shall
become part of the permanent records of the Wickliffe Cemetery; a memorializing
plaque in the scattering garden shall bear the inscription of the name of the
deceased and their date of birth, if known, and date of death.
   (c)   The City accepts its duty to cremate an indigent deceased at its
expense under this section when the body is claimed as an indigent person as
defined aforesaid.
(Ord. 2011-50.  Passed 9-12-11.)
   963.03  FEES.
   Council shall determine fees for service of the cemetery of the City,
including but not limited to, foundation rates, columbarium niche sales, and
interment, after receiving the recommendation of the Board of Cemetery
Trustees.  These fees include, but are not limited to the following:  price per
niche for resident and non-resident; maintenance charge for resident and non-
resident; contract and deed filing fee; interment charge for weekday or
Saturday before 3:00 p.m.; disinterment charges and transfer fees; scattering
garden prices; engraving fees.  Copies of columbarium niche pricing and
scattering garden pricing shall be available at Wickliffe City Hall, Department
of Public Service. 
(Ord. 2011-50.  Passed 9-12-11.)
   963.04  PLANTING AND DECORATING OF GRAVES AND LOTS,  COLUMBARIUM NICHES AND
SCATTERING GARDEN.
   The planting and decorating of graves and lots shall be in accordance with
the following rules:
   (a)    There shall be no planting of shrubs, trees, flowers or bushes of any
kind without the permission of the Board of Cemetery Trustees.
   (b)    No glass blocks shall be used at any time of the year.
   (c)    All Memorial Day or summer flowers or decorations shall be removed
from cemetery grounds by October 15 of each year.
   (d)    Christmas decorations shall be removed from cemetery grounds by March
1 of each year.
   (e)    Easter and Passover flowers and decorations shall be removed within
two weeks following Easter and Passover.
   (f)    Neat artificial flowers may be used, but the right is reserved to
remove such flowers when they appear dirty, broken or uncared for.
   (g)    All potted plants, baskets or urns of flowers that are dead or dried
up from lack of water or neglect shall be removed.
   (h)    Cut flowers are permitted.
   (i)    Flower beds that are established or that have been in a cemetery for
a number of years shall be permitted to remain, but no new flower beds shall be
permitted.
   (j)    Neither the City nor any of its employees shall be responsible for
stolen or broken pots, urns, baskets or vases.
   (k)    During the grass growing season, wreaths, styrofoam religious
symbols, shells, toys, metal designs, ornaments and statues are not permitted.
   (1)    The Service Department may remove all floral designs, flowers, weeds,
trees, shrubs, plants or herbage of any kind from the cemetery as soon as, in
the judgment of the Service Department they become unsightly, dangerous,
detrimental or diseased or when they do not conform to the standards
maintained.
   (m)    The Service Department shall not be responsible for frozen plants,
pots or herbage of any kind or for plantings damaged by the elements, thieves
or other causes beyond its control.
   (n)    The Service Department reserves the right to prevent the removal of
flowers, floral designs, trees, shrubs or herbage of any kind.
   (o)    The Service Department shall undertake to maintain, as may be
practical, the planting of trees and shrubs to preserve and maintain landscape
features, but such persons shall not be required to undertake and maintain
individual plantings, urns or plants.
   (p)    Receptacles for waste material shall be located at convenient places
in the cemetery. The throwing of rubbish on drives and paths or on any part of
the grounds is prohibited.
   (q)    Persons visiting the cemetery or attending funerals are strictly
prohibited from picking flowers, wild or cultivated; from breaking or injuring
any tree, shrub or plant; and from writing upon, defacing or injuring any
memorial, fence or other structure on the cemetery grounds.
   (r)   Only fresh flowers shall be placed at the base of the columbarium.
   (s)   The Service Department shall remove the niche faceplate, and open the
niche.  The family or funeral director may place the urn in the niche. 
Thereafter, the Service Department shall replace the niche faceplate.
   (t)   Inscriptions and engraving shall be completed only during warm months
as directed by the Director of Public Service.
   (u)   Other rules and regulations, if any, are available at Wickliffe City
Hall, Department of Public Service.
      (Ord. 2007-81.  Passed 12-10-07.)
   963.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 1989-74. Passed 10-9-89.)
CHAPTER 965
Green Ridge Municipal Golf Course
965.01   Trespassing upon fenced-in area.
965.02   Golf course season and hours.
965.03   Fees.
965.04   Resident discount.
965.99   Penalty.
   965.01  TRESPASSING UPON FENCED-IN AREA.
   No person shall enter without lawful authority or trespass upon the premises
of the fenced-in area of the municipal golf facility known as Green Ridge Golf
Course during any unauthorized hours. 
(Ord. 2005-39.  Passed 4-11-05.)
   965.02  GOLF COURSE SEASON AND HOURS.
   (a)   Between the dates of March 15 through October 15 each year, the golf
course shall be open from dawn to dusk, weather permitting, as determined by
the Golf Course Manager and/or the Director of Recreation.
   (b)   From October 16 through March 14 each year, the golf course property
shall be open for golf and other community activities, such hours of operation
and nature of activities as will be determined and posted by the Director of
Recreation at the golf course property.
(Ord. 2005-39.  Passed 4-11-05.)
   965.03  FEES.
   The following fees shall be charged for the use of Green Ridge Golf Course:
 
                                  Nine Holes 2nd Nine Holes
(a) Wickliffe residents           $8.00      $800
(b) Seniors                       8.00       8.00
(c) All non-residents             11.00      11.00
(d) Pull cart                     2.00       -0-
(e) Ride cart (one or two riders) 12.00      12.00
(f) Outings and Tournaments       10.00      --
      (Ord.  2006-21.  Passed 4-24-06.)
   965.04  RESIDENT DISCOUNT.
   Each resident of the City of Wickliffe shall be entitled to a discount,
which will be posted at the course as the Wickliffe Resident Rate.  Proof of
residency shall be provided at the time of purchase of greens fees to allow for
the discount.
(Ord. 2006-21.  Passed 4-24-06.)
   965.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of Section
965.01 is guilty of criminal trespass, a misdemeanor of the fourth degree
pursuant to Codified Ordinance No. 541.05.
(Ord. 2005-39.  Passed 4-11-05.)

CHAPTER 1103
Unfair Housing Practices Prohibited
1103.01   Intent.
1103.02   Unfair housing practices.
1103.03   Exemptions.
1103.04   Complaint procedure.
1103.99   Penalty.
 
   1103.01  INTENT.
   It is the intent of Chapter
1103 to assure full and equal opportunity to all residents of the City of
Wickliffe to obtain fair and adequate housing for themselves and their families
in the City of Wickliffe without discrimination against them because of their
race, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, age, religion,
disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, parental status,
military discharge status, or source of income.
(Ord. 2013-10.  Passed 4-8-13.)
   1103.02  UNFAIR HOUSING PRACTICES.
   It shall be an unfair housing practice and unlawful for any owner, lessee,
sub-lessee, assignee, managing agent, or other person, firm or corporation
having the right to sell, rent, lease or sublease any housing accommodation,
within the City of Wickliffe, or any agent of any of these, or any real estate
broker licensed as such:
   (a)   To make any distinction, discrimination, or restriction against any
person in the price, terms, conditions or privileges of any kind relating to
the sale, rental, lease or occupancy of any real estate used for residential
purposes in the City of Wickliffe or in the furnishing of any facilities or
services in connection therewith, predicated upon the race, color, sex, sexual
orientation, gender identity, age, religion, disability, national origin,
ancestry, marital status, parental status, military discharge status or source
of income of the prospective or actual buyer or tenant thereof.
   (b)   To publish, circulate, issue or display, or cause to be published,
circulated, issued or displayed, any communication, notice, advertisement, sign
or other writing of any kind relating to the sale, rental or leasing of any
residential real  property within the City of Wickliffe which will indicate or
express any limitation or discrimination in the sale, rental or leasing of such
residential real estate, predicated upon the race, color, sex, sexual
orientation, gender identity, age, religion, disability, national origin,
ancestry, marital status, parental status, military discharge status or source
of income of any prospective buyer, lessee or renter of such property.
   (c)   To refuse to sell, lease or rent, any real estate for residential
purposes within the City of Wickliffe because of the race, color, sex, sexual
orientation, gender identity, age, religion, disability, national origin,
ancestry, marital status, parental status, military discharge status or source
of income of the proposed buyer or renter.
   (d)   To discriminate or to participate in discrimination in connection with
borrowing or lending money, guaranteeing loans, accepting mortgages or
otherwise obtaining or making available funds for the purchase, acquisition,
construction, rehabilitation, repair or maintenance of any residential housing
unit or housing accommodation in the City of Wickliffe because of race, color,
sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, age, religion, disability, national
origin, ancestry, marital status, parental status, military discharge status or
source of income.
   (e)   To solicit for sale, lease or listing for sale or lease, residential
real estate within the City of Wickliffe on the ground of loss of value due to
the present or prospective entry into any neighborhood of any person or persons
of any particular race, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, age,
religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, parental
status, military discharge status or source of income.
   (f)   To distribute or cause to be distributed, written material or
statements designed to induce any owner of residential real estate in the City
of Wickliffe to sell or lease his property because of any present or
prospective change in the race, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender
identity, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status,
parental status, military discharge status or source of income of persons in
the neighborhood.
   (g)   To deliberately and knowingly refuse examination of any listing of
residential real estate within the City of Wickliffe to any person because of
race, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, age, religion,
disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, parental status,
military discharge status or source of income.
   (h)   Chapter
1103  - Unfair Housing Practices Prohibited, shall be applicable to all hotels
and motels within the City of Wickliffe.
      (Ord. 2013-10.  Passed 4-8-13.)
   1103.03  EXEMPTIONS.
   No provision of this chapter shall be construed to prohibit any of the
following:
   (a)   Restricting rental or sale of a housing accommodation to a person of a
certain age group:
      (1)    When such housing accommodation is authorized, approved, financed
or subsidized in whole or in part for the benefit of that age group by a unit
of state, local or federal government; or
      (2)    When the duly recorded initial declaration of a condominium of
community association limits such housing accommodations to persons above the
age of 50; provided, that a person or the immediate family of a person owning
or renting a unit in such housing accommodation prior to the recording of the
initial declaration shall not be deemed to be in violation of the age
restriction so long as the person or the person’s immediate family continue to
own or reside in the housing accommodation.
   (b)   A religious organization, association or society, or any not-for-
profit institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in
conjunction with a religious organization, association or society, from
limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of a dwelling which it owns or operates
for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or from
giving preference to such persons of the same religion, or from giving
preference to such persons, unless membership in such religion is restricted on
account of race, color or national origin.
      (Ord. 2013-10.  Passed 4-8-13.)
   1103.04  COMPLAINT PROCEDURE.
   Any person aggrieved in any manner by any violation of this chapter may file
a written complaint with the Director of Public Safety.  The complaint shall
include the name and address of the complainant and of every person against
whom the complaint is made, and shall set out the facts giving rise to the
complaint.  No person shall refuse or fail to comply with any subpoena, order
or decision issued in the course of or as a result of an investigation of a
complaint.
(Ord. 2009-30.  Passed 6-8-09.)
   1103.99  PENALTY.
   Any owner, lessee, sub-lessee, assignee, managing agent, or other person,
firm, corporation, or real estate broker, who shall violate or fail to comply
with any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree.  Nothing herein contained shall be construed so as to
preclude any aggrieved person from pursuing such other and further legal and
equitable relief to which he may be entitled.
(Ord. 2009-30.  Passed 6-8-09.)
CHAPTER 1105
Division of Building Engineering and Inspection
1105.01   Establishment.
1105.02   Appointment of Commissioner; removal.
1105.03   Interpretation and enforcement.
1105.04   Rules.
1105.05   Examination and approval of plans and specifications.
1105.06   Authentication of permits and certificates.
1105.07   Records.
1105.08   Information and data for public use.
1105.09   Reports; recommendations for amendments.
1105.10   Enforcement; conflict of law.
1105.11   Appeals.
1105.12   Car allowance.
1105.99   General Building Code penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate building erection - see Ohio R.C. 715.26, 715.29,
737.28, 737.37
      Administration of Zoning Ordinance by Commissioner - see P. & Z. 1303.20
et seq.
      Fire damaged structures; removal or repair securing fund - see BLDG.
1159.08
   1105.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established in the Department of Public Safety a Division of
Building Engineering and Inspection to be administered and controlled by a
Building Commissioner, subject to the provisions of the
Charter and ordinances of the City and to the direction of the Director of
Public Safety. 
(Ord. 1953-20.  Passed 4-13-53.)
   1105.02  APPOINTMENT OF COMMISSIONER; REMOVAL.
   The Building Commissioner shall be appointed by the Director of Public
Safety with the concurrence of two thirds of all members elected to Council and
may be removed by the Director of Public Safety.  However, such removal shall
not be effected without the concurrence of two- thirds of all members elected
to Council. Such appointee shall be in the classified service and subject to
civil service.  [“Classified service” means the competitive classified civil
service of the City of Wickliffe, Section 124.01(c), Ohio Revised Code.]
   1105.03  INTERPRETATION AND ENFORCEMENT.
   The Building Commissioner shall interpret, administer and enforce the
building, electrical and plumbing ordinances of the City and any other
ordinances now in effect or hereafter created or passed relating to the
construction of any building, of whatever character and for whatever purpose
the same may be used, and interpret and enforce the Zoning Ordinance of the
City and perform such other and additional duties as may from time to time be
imposed upon him by law, the City
Charter or ordinance.
(Ord. 1953-20. Passed 4-13-53.)
   1105.04  RULES.
   The Building Commissioner shall prescribe such rules as he believes
necessary for the performance of the work of the Division of Building
Engineering and Inspection.
(Ord. 1953-20. Passed 4-13-53.)
   1105.05  EXAMINATION AND APPROVAL OF PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS.
   The Building Commissioner shall pass upon all questions relating to the
strength and durability of buildings and materials, or either, and shall
examine, approve or cause to be examined and approved, all plans and
specifications filed with applications for permits before permits are issued;
provided however, that the Building Commissioner shall not modify in any way
site plans, parking plans, elevations of buildings, drainage plans and
specifications, fences, landscape features, access drives, buffer zones, and
any other conditions which may have been approved by the Planning Commission,
without first submitting such modifications to the Planning Commission for its
approval.
(Ord. 1978-70. Passed 12-26-78.)
   1105.06  AUTHENTICATION OF PERMITS AND CERTIFICATES.
   The Building Commissioner shall sign or cause to be signed all permits and
certificates issued by the Division of Building Engineering and Inspection.
(Ord. 1953-20. Passed 4-13-53.)
   1105.07  RECORDS.
   The Building Commissioner shall keep, or cause to be kept in his office, a
complete record of all applications, plans and specifications submitted, of all
permits and certificates issued, and of all investigations and examinations
held or made by him, his assistants or other employees of the Division of
Building Engineering and Inspection.
(Ord. 1953-20. Passed 4-13-53.)
   1105.08  INFORMATION AND DATA FOR PUBLIC USE.
   The Building Commissioner shall develop, compile and currently maintain, or
cause to be developed, compiled and currently maintained, pertinent
information, statistics and related data on housing and building for public
examination.
(Ord. 1953-20. Passed 4-13-53.)
   1105.09  REPORTS; RECOMMENDATIONS FOR AMENDMENTS.
   The Building Commissioner shall promptly acknowledge receipt of all official
communications, notices and reports and he shall annually, not later than June
1, submit a report to the Director of Public Safety covering the work of the
Division of Building Engineering and Inspection, during the preceding calendar
year, and his recommendations for desirable amendments to the building,
plumbing and electrical ordinances, or any other code or codes relating to
structures or buildings of every character, and the Zoning Ordinance of the
City.
(Ord. 1953-20. Passed 4-13-53.)
   1105.10  ENFORCEMENT; CONFLICT OF LAW.
   Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary contained in any other code or
ordinance of the City, the Building Commissioner shall administer and enforce
any and all provisions of law or ordinance relating to the use, occupancy,
maintenance and safety of all buildings and dwellings.
   Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to relieve any other officer from
any duty  imposed upon him by law or ordinance.
(Ord. 1953-20. Passed 4-13-53.)
   1105.11  APPEALS.
   Any person or the head of any department or division of the City aggrieved
by a decision of the Building Commissioner may appeal such decision to the
Board of Zoning Appeals in the manner provided in Chapter 1335 of the Planning
and Zoning Code.
   1105.12  CAR ALLOWANCE .
   The Building Commissioner shall receive a monthly allowance for each month
that he uses his private automobile in the discharge of his duties.
(Ord. 1953-20. Passed 4-13-53.)
   1105.99  GENERAL BUILDING CODE PENALTY.
   (a)    Whoever fails or neglects promptly to notify the administrative
officer having jurisdiction that work under a permit issued pursuant to the
provisions of the Building Code has been started; or
   (b)    Whoever performs any construction work or installs any permanently
placed or fixed device or equipment without first securing a permit required
therefor under the provisions of the Building Code; or refuses, neglects or
fails to secure any permit required under the provisions of the Building Code
for the storage, use or handling of a hazardous substance; or blocks, wedge or
otherwise hold in an open position any self-closing door required under the
provisions of the Building Code to be maintained in a normally closed position;
or
   (c)    Whoever perpetrates a fraud or misrepresents a material fact by
reason of which any permit or approval required under the provisions of the
Building Code is obtained; or pursues any trade or business or performs any
work or service for which a license or certificate of registration is required
under the provisions of the Building Code, without possessing such required
valid license or certificate of registration; or
   (d)    Whoever refuses, neglects or fails to comply with an order to stop
work issued under the provisions of the Building Code; or refuses, neglects or
fails to comply with a notice to repair, rehabilitate or demolish a building or
other structure declared to be unsafe under the provisions of the Building
Code; or refuses, neglects or fails to comply with a notice requiring the
abatement or removal of a violation or requiring compliance with any provision
of the Building Code or any rule or regulation thereunder within the time limit
set forth in such notice; or maintains a use or occupancy prohibited by the
Building Code; or refuses, neglects or fails to maintain stair enclosures,
stairways, fire escapes, exit passageways or other required means of egress in
a safe and usable condition as required by the Building Code; or
   (e)    Whoever violates any other provision of the Building Code or any rule
or regulations promulgated thereunder, except Section
1161.05(a), or who fails to comply therewith or with any order issued
thereunder, or causes or permits the same to be done, is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months or both. Each day
during which noncompliance or a violation continues shall constitute a separate
offense.
   (f)    The imposition of any penalty shall not preclude the Director of Law
from instituting an appropriate action or proceeding in a court of proper
jurisdiction to prevent an unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction,
alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance or use, or to restrain, correct or
abate a violation, or to prevent the occupancy of a building, structure or
premises, or to prevent an illegal act, conduct, business or use, in or about
any premises, or to require compliance with provisions of this Code or other
applicable laws, ordinances, rules or regulations or the orders or
determinations of the Commissioner of Buildings or the Board of Zoning Appeals.

(Ord. 1990-60. Passed 10-8-90.)
CHAPTER 1106
Grading and Draining
1106.01   Objective.
1106.02   Surface drainage.
1106.03   Footing drains.
1106.04   Backfill over footing drains.
1106.05   Roof and yard drainage; disconnection permits.
CROSS REFERENCES
Site and grading plans - see BLDG. Ch.
1107
   1106.01  OBJECTIVE.
   It shall be the objective of grading regulations to provide grading which
shall divert surface water away from buildings and dispose of such water
without harmful effects on neighboring property to preserve desirable site
features and to provide grades and gradients for safe and convenient access to
and around buildings and lot for their normal use and maintenance. The final
grade at the building shall not be closer than eight inches to the wood or
other corrodible siding or exterior trim.
(Ord. 1986-21. Passed 4-28-86.)
   1106.02  SURFACE DRAINAGE.
   (a)    Positive drainage shall be provided for each lot or plot by proper
draining so that a nuisance shall not be created. Catch basins and in some
cases properly connected under-drains shall be installed, or other approved
provisions made where water may pocket, to preclude the accumulation of surface
water. Regrading shall be done so that existing natural ground drainage of the
surrounding area shall not be impeded.
   (b)    The Building Commissioner may adopt rules or plans for the drainage
of lots or plots which rules or plans shall be followed by the owner unless
permission for deviation is given by the Planning Commission and/or Board of
Zoning Appeals. When a lot or plot is graded to a higher or lower level than
the natural grade on an adjacent property, the owner of such lot or plot shall
provide suitable slopes or retaining walls or other protection approved by the
Building Commissioner on his own property to preserve the natural slope of
surface elevation of such adjacent property.
(Ord. 1986-21. Passed 4-28-86.)
   1106.03  FOOTING DRAINS.
   When a floor is below the adjoining ground and subsoil conditions are such
as to permit ground water to accumulate adjacent to the foundation, footing
drains shall be installed alongside the outside face of the base of the
foundation. Such drains shall be not less than four inches diameter pipe of a
type and construction to intercept and carry ground water without permitting
the infiltration of soil into the pipe. Footing drains shall have a continuous
slope of not less than one-sixteenth inch per foot, discharging into the
building storm sewer or other outlet approved by the Building Commissioner.
(Ord. 1986-21. Passed 4-28-86.)
   1106.04  BACKFILL OVER FOOTING DRAINS.
   The backfill over footing drains shall be pervious material of the type,
size and graduation required for the particular type of drain construction
being used and shall be carried up at least eighteen inches over drain tile but
not closer than twelve inches of the established surface grade. The top twelve
inches of the backfill shall consist of six inches of an impervious (clay)
soil, topped with six inches of a clayey top soil if the surface is to be
covered with lawn or shrubs. If the surface adjacent to the foundation wall is
to be paved or have some similar treatment, then the backfill near the top may
be a suitable base for such construction.
(Ord. 1986-21. Passed 4-28-86.)
   1106.05  ROOF AND YARD DRAINAGE; DISCONNECTION PERMITS.
   Unless otherwise specifically approved by the Building Commissioner, roof
drainage shall be handled by suitable collectors and downspouts, which shall
discharge into a sealed, jointed storm drain of not less than four-inch
diameter with a slope of one-fourth inch or more per foot.  Where a storm sewer
or other storm drainage outlet is not available or where a disconnection permit
application is submitted and granted, downspouts may discharge onto other
devices approved by the Building Commissioner provided that no excess water
shall flow onto adjoining property or over sidewalks.  A disconnection permit
shall be revoked upon evidence that excess water flows onto adjoining property
or over sidewalks.  The storm drain outlet carrying roof water or yard drainage
shall be not less than six-inch diameter and shall not connect to the footing
drain, but may intercept and receive the outlet of the footing drainage by a
wye connection above the spring line.  Connection of any pipe carrying roof
water or yard drainage to a sanitary sewer is prohibited.
(Ord. 2014-33.  Passed 7-14-14.)
CHAPTER 1107
Site and Grading Plans
1107.01   Preliminary site plan requirements.
1107.02   Approval of preliminary site plan; finished ground grade and grade of
foundation.
1107.03   Final site plan.
1107.04   Deposit, costs and fees.
1107.05   Provision for drainage of surface water required.
1107.06   Conflicts.
1107.07   Violations.
1107.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Grading and drainage - see BLDG. Ch.
1106
   1107.01  PRELIMINARY SITE PLAN REQUIREMENTS.
   In addition to all other requirements of the Building and Zoning Code and
ordinances or statutes of the City, the County and the State, and before a
building permit is issued by the Building Commissioner for a building, a person
who owns, leases or is in possession or control of any property who desires to
construct a new building or structure, or to remodel or reconstruct an existing
building or structure wherein the existing grade of the lot or building is
proposed to be changed, or a person seeking to change the grade of any property
by more than four inches, shall, in addition to obtaining all other permits
required by the City, County and State, submit to the Building Commissioner an
application for a permit, the required deposit and three copies of the site
plan of the property, prepared by a registered civil engineer or a registered
surveyor, showing where such proposed construction or reconstruction is or
shall be situated and showing, as applicable, the following:
   (a)    The existing elevation of the centerline of the street;
   (b)    The existing elevation of the top of the nearest street curb, if any;
   (c)    The existing elevation of the top of the nearest portion of the
sidewalk, if any;
   (d)    The existing elevation at each corner of the lot;
   (e)    The first or main floor elevation and the location of adjacent
buildings within twenty-five feet of all property lines;
   (f)    The elevations of the existing grade and proposed finished grade of
the lot on a suitable contour interval (flat terrain - one foot; hilly terrain
- two foot);
   (g)    The proposed elevation of the first or main floor of the building,
garage and the finished ground grade at the building corners;
   (h)    The foundation and/or slab elevation;
   (i)    The bearings and lot dimensions, the lot and block number or lot and
tract number, all easements of record, an arrow showing the north direction and
the street name;
   (j)    A reference bench mark established on some permanent object in the
near vicinity which shall remain undisturbed during construction and available
for elevation checks. The bench mark may be assumed to be 100 feet where a City
bench mark is not available;
   (k)    The location, elevation and size of all existing and proposed on-site
sanitary systems, sanitary sewers, water lines and storm sewers in or adjacent
to the lot;
   (l)    Dimensions of proposed or existing buildings, set back, side and rear
yard dimensions;
   (m)    Size and invert elevations of driveway culverts, if any;
   (n)    The existing conditions of the road ditch, if any, in front of the
property at twenty- five foot intervals;
   (o)    For residential developments, the location and dimensions of a
garage, even though the construction of a garage is not included in the
application;
   (p)    The location and dimensions of proposed driveways and sidewalks;
   (q)    For nonresidential developments, location and dimensions of parking
areas, spaces, aisles and the location on proposed building of main doors and
any overhead door openings;
   (r)    The proposed elevation and location of yard drains;
   (s)    A certification by a registered surveyor that the property has been
surveyed and iron pins set at all lot corners and angle points and a tie to the
nearest intersecting street;
   (t)    Any other information that the Building Commissioner may require,
such as details, computations, stress diagrams and other data necessary to
describe the construction and basis for calculations; and
   (u)    Any other information that may be required by the City Engineer to
assure that the proposed building elevations and site grading are compatible
with adjacent property and that positive drainage is achieved.
      (Ord. 1986-57. Passed 11-24-86.)
   1107.02  APPROVAL OF PRELIMINARY SITE PLAN; FINISHED GROUND GRADE AND GRADE
OF FOUNDATION.
   (a)    Upon receipt of the application and site plan, as described in
Section
1107.01, the Building Commissioner shall, if all other aspects of the
application for the permit are in order, submit a copy of the application and
site plan to the City Engineer. The Engineer shall examine such site plan for
conformity to the proper relation with existing or proposed sanitary sewers,
water lines, storm drainage and existing grades of adjacent lands and
buildings, following the guidelines of subsection (b) hereof. If the plan does
not so conform, the Engineer shall call the applicant's attention to the lack
of conformity and require that the plan be changed in that respect. When the
Engineer finds that the plan so conforms, he or she shall approve the same and
return it to the Building Commissioner. Such approved plan shall be a condition
of any permit which may be issued pursuant to this chapter for such
construction. It shall then be the responsibility of the applicant to perform
all work in conformity with the various grades and elevations of the final
approved site plan and to set witness markers clearly designating the lot
corners.
   (b)    The finished ground grade of each building shall be established in
proper relation to the surrounding grade, driveway and street. The lot shall be
graded so that water drains away from each building at a minimum grade of two
percent (2%). Surface drainage swales shall have a minimum grade designed so
that surface water shall drain onto a driveway, street gutter, storm sewer,
drain inlet or natural drainage way. The minimum grades of driveways shall be
four-tenths percent (.4%), and a maximum of fifteen percent (15%). Grading
shall be adjusted so there shall be no abrupt grades in the front yards and
along side lot lines. The grades of earth terraces shall not exceed two and
one-half to one. If a masonry retaining wall exceeds three feet in height, a
hedge, fence or railing shall be provided.
   (c)    At such time as the builder or other permit holder has constructed
the foundation or slab referred to in Section
1107.01(h), he or she shall request, through the Building Commissioner, that
the City Engineer check the grade. No further construction shall be permitted
until the Engineer has checked the elevation of such foundation and found it to
be in accordance with the site plan approved pursuant to subsection (a) hereof.
   (d)    When the builder or other permit holder has constructed the subbase
of the hard surface paved area and other areas that require grade changes, as
indicated on their submitted approved plan, the permit holder shall request,
through the Building Commissioner, that the City Engineer check the grade. No
further construction shall be permitted until the City Engineer has checked the
elevation of the required areas and found it to be in accordance with the plot
plan approved pursuant to subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 1986-57. Passed 11-24-86.)
   1107.03  FINAL SITE PLAN.
   Upon completion of construction and before a certificate of occupancy is
issued for a building by the Building Commissioner, each applicant shall file
with the City Engineer a final plot plan, which shall show the final grades of
the improvement as constructed. Such plan shall be certified, by a registered
civil engineer or surveyor, as to the accuracy of the plan in depicting the
actual construction. Such civil engineer or surveyor shall also certify that he
or she has made an actual field observation of as-built conditions and that
such conditions are as shown on the plan. The form of such certification shall
be prescribed by the City Engineer.
(Ord. 1986-57. Passed 11-24-86.)
   1107.04  DEPOSIT, COSTS AND FEES.
   (a)    The Building Commissioner shall collect a deposit based on the
following schedule, in addition to any other permit fees, at the time of the
application for the permit.
 
      (1)    Site plan for single-famil$600.00
         residential construction
      (2)    Site plan for multi-family600.00
         residential construction
      (3)    Site plan for commercial a1,200.00
         industrial construction
      (4)   Site plan fee for institutional and
         recreation; senior/adult resid1,200,00
         districts construction
(Ord. 2010-07.  Passed 4-12-10.)
   The City Engineer shall estimate the cost of the site plan review. If the
estimated cost exceeds the deposit, the applicant shall be informed of the
estimated costs and shall be directed to deposit the difference between the
Engineer's estimate and the applicant's original deposit, which difference
shall be deposited prior to the Engineer's examination of such site plan.
   (b)    The applicant shall be charged for the actual costs incurred by the
City Engineer for the review of the site plan, inspection of the site and
checking of the grade, and any and all other expenses associated with the site
plan review. Such costs shall be computed on the basis and in accordance with
the legislation governing the right of compensation for the City Engineer at
the time. Any deficiency between the actual costs of the services rendered by
the City Engineer and the deposit paid by the applicant, shall be paid to the
City prior to the approval of the final site plan. Any excess of the deposit
over the actual costs of the City Engineer and the permit fee shall be returned
to the applicant.
   (c)    All costs and fees paid pursuant to this chapter shall be deposited
in the general fund of the City.
(Ord. 1986-57. Passed 11-24-86.)
   1107.05  PROVISION FOR DRAINAGE OF SURFACE WATER REQUIRED.
   In addition to the requirements of this chapter or of any ordinance adopted
by the City, wherever the site plan filed under Section
1107.01 fails to indicate a method of positive draining of surface water from
the lot, the City Engineer shall notify the applicant of such failure and the
applicant shall be required to correct such deficiency before resubmission for
approval.
(Ord. 1986-57. Passed 11-24-86.)
   1107.06  CONFLICTS.
   This chapter is not intended to repeal, abrogate or impair Chapters
1106 and
1109, but is deemed to be supplemental thereto. Wherever this chapter and
Chapters
1106 and
1109, or any other valid ordinance, building code or restriction, conflict or
overlap, the more stringent restriction shall prevail.
(Ord. 1986-57. Passed 11-24-86.)
   1107.07  VIOLATIONS.
   No person shall violate or cause or knowingly permit to be violated any of
the provisions of this chapter, or fail to comply with any such provisions, or
fail to comply with any lawful requirement of any public authority made
pursuant to this chapter, or knowingly use or cause or permit the use of any
lands in violation hereof, or in violation of any permit granted hereunder.
(Ord. 1986-57. Passed 11-24-86.)
   1107.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty
days, or both, for each offense. Each day during which such violation continues
shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 1986-57. Passed 11-24-86.)
CHAPTER 1108
Tree Management  (Repealed)

CHAPTER 1109
Permits and Fees
1109.01   Building Commissioner to prepare permits, collect fees.
1109.02   Deposit for damage to tree lawn or sidewalk.
1109.03   Fee for additional inspection.
1109.04   Plot plan may be required.
1109.05   Setting grade. (Repealed)
1109.06   Utility or service poles.
1109.07   Public or quasi-public buildings.
1109.08   New single, double or triplex dwellings.
1109.09   Garages or accessory buildings.
1109.10   Additions or alterations to dwellings.

1167.09
   1109.01  BUILDING COMMISSIONER TO PREPARE PERMITS, COLLECT FEES.
   (a)   The Building Commissioner shall prepare each permit, designate thereon
the character and size of the building or structure, establish the fee to be
paid in accordance with the fees set forth in this Building Code, collect the
fee and issue a receipt for it.
   (b)   All permits shall be obtained from the Building Commissioner prior to
and/or before construction.  Pursuant to Chapter
1109, any work starting and/or beginning without proper permits shall be
charged two times (2X) the codified permit fee.
(Ord. 2011-75.  Passed 1-9-12.)
   1109.02  DEPOSIT FOR DAMAGE TO TREE LAWN OR SIDEWALK.
   A deposit of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be required with each
permit issued for the construction, alteration or repair of any building; the
deposit shall be retained as a guarantee against damage to the sidewalk or tree
lawn in the vicinity of the building or structure for which the permit is
issued from any cause whatsoever growing out of or in conjunction with the work
prosecuted under the permit.
(Ord. 1990-61. Passed 8-2-90.)
   1109.03  FEE FOR ADDITIONAL INSPECTION.
   Whenever an inspection has been requested and the work to be inspected
pursuant to the request is found incomplete or not ready for inspection, and it
is necessary to make another visit for the inspection, there shall be charged
an additional fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
(Ord. 1990-37. Passed 8-2-90.)
   1109.04  PLOT PLAN MAY BE REQUIRED.
   The Building Commissioner may require a plot plan created by a qualified
surveyor showing the topography of the site, and the location of the proposed
building or structure for which an application for a permit has been filed and
of every existing building or structure on the site or lot, and of buildings
and structures on adjoining property together with the topography of the
adjoining property. He may also require details, computations, stress diagrams
and other data necessary to describe the construction and basis for
calculations.
(Ord. 1982-32. Passed 5-10-82.)
   1109.05  SETTING GRADE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 1986-57, passed
November 24, 1986.)
   1109.06  UTILITY OR SERVICE POLES.
   (a)    No plat shall be approved for dedication, unless provisions are made
for all utilities to be installed underground in all future developments.
   (b)   No person shall install utility poles or any poles of whatever
character in the tree lawn of any street or on any public property unless the
written consent of the Mayor or the Director of Public Service has first been
obtained to do so.
   (c)   The Mayor or the Director of Public Service may, in his discretion,
permit the installation of utility or service poles in the tree lawn of any
street or on public property, if, in his opinion, such installation is the only
feasible method.
(Ord.  1984-88.  Passed 11-12-84.)
   1109.07  PUBLIC OR QUASI-PUBLIC BUILDINGS.
   (a)    The permit fee for each public or quasi-public building such as a
school, assembly hall, hospital, theater, hotel, club store, apartment, motel,
warehouse, factory and any other building not hereinafter specifically
mentioned, shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) to which shall be added
two dollars ($2.00) for each 100 square feet or fraction thereof of floor area
in each floor to be constructed.
   (b)    The permit fee for an addition or alteration to a public or quasi-
public building shall be:
      (1)    Addition increasing floor area: two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) to which shall be added two dollars ($2.00) for each 100 square feet
or fraction thereof of floor area.
      (2)    Alteration not increasing floor area: two hundred dollars
($200.00) to which shall be added four dollars ($4.00) for each one thousand
dollars ($1,000) of estimated cost or fraction thereof of the alteration.
         (Ord. 2017-28.  Passed 6-26-17.)
   1109.08  NEW SINGLE, DOUBLE OR TRIPLEX DWELLINGS.
   (a)    For new single, double, or triplex dwellings, fees shall be
determined by the square foot aggregate floor area in the following manner: Two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) plus four dollars ($4.00) for each 100 square
feet or fraction thereof.
   (b)    The term "aggregate floor area" as used in this section means the
total square foot area of the basement, habitable rooms, enclosed porches, and
unfinished attics or third floor which are capable of being or can be finished
for habitable purposes, of new single, double, or triplex dwellings. However,
if any law or ordinance prohibits the use of an attic or third floor for
habitation, then the square foot area thereof shall not be included for the
purpose of determining the fee.
(Ord. 2017-28.  Passed 6-26-17.)
   1109.09  GARAGES OR ACCESSORY BUILDINGS.
   (a)    The permit fee for a garage shall be five dollars ($5.00) for each
100 square feet of floor area or fraction thereof, with a minimum fee of eighty
dollars ($80.00).
   (b)    The permit fee for a tool shed or similar structure shall be sixty
dollars ($60.00).  (Ord. 2017-28.  Passed 6-26-17.)

   1109.13  DEMOLITION FEE; BOND.
   (a)   Any person or firm desiring to demolish a building in the City shall,
prior to demolishing the building, secure a permit from the Building
Commissioner for the demolition of the building.  A fee of one hundred dollars
($100.00) shall be charged for the permit.
(Ord. 2017-28.  Passed 6-26-17.)
   (b)   Before any permit is issued allowing the demolition of any building,
the applicant must furnish a bond satisfactory to the Building Commissioner to
protect the City against any liability that might accrue because of injury to
persons or property in connection with the demolition work.  (Ord.  1988-24. 
Passed 5-11-98.)

   1109.15  ELECTRICAL INSTALLATIONS.
   (a)   Wiring.  The minimum fee for any electrical permit is five dollars
($5.00) to which shall be added the following charges for each unit installed
or altered:

provided:
         First 50      $.25
         Over 50       .10
      (2)   For each lighting fixture, except as otherwise provided:
         First 50      $.25
         Over 50       .05
      (3)   When fixtures contain more than four fluorescent or other similar
electrical discharge type tubes, each four tubes shall be deemed a separate
lighting fixture.
      (4)   Each four lineal feet of continuous neon or similar tubing shall be
deemed a separate lighting fixture.
      (5)   Outlets installed twenty-four inches or less on centers as in strip
lighting, marquee lighting, footlights, etc., ten cents (10¢) each.
   (b)   Motors and Generators.  The permit fee for the first motor or
generator less than one horsepower is one dollar ($1.00); for one to five
horsepower, two dollars ($2.00); for over five horsepower, three dollars
($3.00) and one dollar ($1.00) for each additional motor or generator.
   (c)   Furnace, Stove, Rectifier, Welder.  The permit fee for each electric
furnace, stove, rectifier, or welder is two dollars ($2.00).
(Ord.  1982-32.  Passed 5-10-82.)
   1109.16  CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY.
   (a)   Each applicant for a certificate of occupancy shall be furnished with
a printed application form.  The Building Commissioner shall maintain his
office a record of all applications and of all certificates of occupancy issued
by him.
(Ord. 1998-24.  Passed 5-11-98.)
   (b)   A fee of sixty dollars ($60.00) shall be charged for each certificate
of occupancy.  (Ord. 2017-28.  Passed 6-26-17.)
   (c)   The Building Commissioner is hereby empowered to examine and inspect
any building or structure and further to issue a removal order where he finds
that a building or structure is used before the issuance of a certificate of
occupancy where one is required.
   (d)   All persons or corporations occupying or using any building or
structure, together with the owner and any person or corporation who was
employed as a building or contractor for any construction or alteration where a
certificate of occupancy is required but has not been issued, shall be deemed
in violation of the mandates or directives set forth in any order of the
Building Commissioner and/or of the provisions of this section or Section
1303.70. 
(Ord.  1998-24.  Passed 5-11-98.)
   1109.17  MOVING A BUILDING; BOND.
   (a)   No person shall move or cause to be moved any building through any
street without the written permission of the Building Commissioner, and no
person moving any building shall permit it to stand on any street, lane, alley
or public ground for a longer period than three days, and in no case shall it
prevent or interfere with the operation of traffic, without a special permit
covering the right to do so.
   (b)   For moving any building or other structure the permit fee is fifty
dollars ($50.00).
   (c)   Before any permit is issued allowing the moving of any building along
any route, the applicant must furnish a bond satisfactory to the Building
Commissioner providing for the payment of any damages which may occur to any
tree, pavement, street or sidewalk or to any pole or telephone, telegraph or
light wire for which repair the City may be held responsible, whether the
damage is inflicted by the permit holder or his agents, employees or workmen. 
The bond shall hold the City harmless against any liability, judgment, damage,
cost and expense which may in any way accrue against the City in consequence of
granting the permit or the performance of any work thereunder.
(Ord.  1982-32.  Passed 5-10-82.)
   1109.18  FENCES.
   (a)   No fence shall hereafter be erected, altered, relocated or
reconstructed unless information is first presented to the Building
Commissioner showing the location, dimensions and the manner of construction of
the fence, and the Building Commissioner has issued a permit for the same.  No
person shall commence any such work unless a permit has first been obtained.
   (b)   A fee of sixty dollars ($60.00) shall be charged for each fence permit
issued.
 
   (c)   No fence permit shall be granted, if in the opinion of the Building
Commissioner the construction, alteration, relocation or reconstruction of the
proposed fence will constitute a nuisance, fire hazard, traffic hazard or
menace.
(Ord.  1998-24.  Passed 5-11-98; Ord. 2006-25.  Passed 5-22-06; Ord. 2017-28. 
Passed 6-26-17.)

CHAPTER 1112
Registration of Contractors
1112.01   Definitions.
1112.02   Registration required.
1112.03   Application; registration fee; renewal fee.
1112.04   General contractor information; bond; insurance.
1112.05   Certificate fees.  (Repealed)
1112.06   Conditions for certificate renewal.
1112.07   Revocation of certificate.
1112.08   Appeals.
1112.09   Disposition of fees; records.
1112.10   Homeowner's exception.
1112.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Material purchased by contractor; wrongful use - see Ohio R.C.  2911.31
      Frauds by contractor of public works - see Ohio R.C. 2919.14
   
   1112.01  DEFINITIONS.
   "General contractor", as used within this chapter, means any individual,
firm, partnership, corporation, association or other organization, or any
combination thereof, who or which by himself or itself, or by or through
others, constructs, alters, repairs, adds to, subtracts from, reconstructs or
remodels any building, structure or appurtenance thereto, or who or which
undertakes or offers to undertake, or purports to have the capacity to
undertake, or submits a bid to do so. "General contractor" includes
subcontractors and all specialty contractors whose operations as such are the
performance of construction work requiring skills and whose principal business
involves the use of specialized building trades or crafts.
(Ord. 1987-61. Passed 1-25-88.)
   1112.02  REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   No general contractor shall perform any work, for hire or otherwise, in the
City without first obtaining a certificate of registration from the Building
Commissioner.
(Ord. 1987-61. Passed 1-25-88.)
   1112.03  APPLICATION; REGISTRATION FEE; RENEWAL FEE.
   (a)   Application for a certificate of registration shall be upon a form
provided by the Building Commissioner and shall be accompanied by a
registration fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).  The application form shall
include space for the true name, current address, and telephone number of the
contractor applying, and designate the form of business organization, whether
corporation, partnership, individual or other organization.  When the applicant
is other than an individual, he shall state the name, address and telephone
number of an individual charged with the management of the work of the business
organization to be performed within the City.  The application shall contain
such other information as the Building Commissioner deems pertinent.
   (b)   Upon the filing of the application and bond, if they are in conformity
with the provisions of this chapter, the Building Commissioner is hereby
directed to issue to applicants who have given satisfactory proof of the
knowledge of the essentials of the business in which they intend to engage, a
certificate of registration upon payment of the above-stated fee.
   (c)   The certificate of registration shall be for the term of one calendar
year, commencing on January 1 and ending on December 31, and may be renewed
annually upon the payment of a renewal fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 2011-76.  Passed 12-12-11.)
   1112.04  GENERAL CONTRACTOR INFORMATION; BOND; INSURANCE.
   (a)    Each applicant for a certificate of registration as a general
contractor shall file with the Building Commissioner a written application
which shall state the applicant's name and residence, his business address, his
experience in the business in which he intends to engage, and any other
information the Building Commissioner may require.
   (b)    The application shall be accompanied by a bond made payable to the
City, in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000) with sureties to the
approval of the Building Commissioner, conditioned that the applicant shall
indemnify and save harmless the City and the inhabitants thereof from any and
all damages on account of negligence or inadequate or faulty work upon the part
of the applicant, his servants or employees, or on account of his or their
failure to comply with the regulations of the City and the State relating to
the same.
 
   (c)    The applicant shall furnish evidence of liability insurance for
bodily injury in the minimum amount of one hundred thousand dollars/three
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000/$300,000) and for property damage in the
minimum amount of twenty-five thousand dollars/fifty thousand dollars ($25,000/
$50,000).
(Ord. 2002-54.  Passed 11-25-02.)
   1112.05  CERTIFICATE FEES.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
1112.05 was repealed by Ordinance 2011-76.)
   1112.06  CONDITIONS FOR CERTIFICATE RENEWAL.
   The Building Commissioner shall issue a renewal certificate of registration
to any contractor who has been issued an original certificate of registration;
has updated his original application by making any changes that have occurred
in the information contained on his original application; has renewed his bond
and offers evidence of continuing liability insurance coverage in the same
amounts and form as is required for issuance of an original certificate of
registration; has tendered payment for the renewal certificate of registration
fee in the amount set forth in Section
1112.05; and where the contractor's records of work in the City does not show
repeated violations of the Building Code of the City, this to be determined by
the Building Commissioner.
(Ord. 1987-61. Passed 1-25-88.)
   1112.07  REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE.
   The Building Commissioner is authorized and directed to revoke any original
or renewal certificate of registration when in his opinion the certificate
holder has performed work in a careless and irregular manner resulting in
repeated and continuing violations of the Building Code of the City or when the
Building Commissioner has evidence that the liability insurance and/or bond
coverage required is no longer in effect.
   The Building Commissioner shall give notice of such revocation to the
contractor by certified mail directed to the contractor at the address
appearing on the current application stating in detail the facts and
conclusions upon which the revocation is based. The notice shall also contain a
copy of Section
1112.08 setting forth appellate procedures from the order of revocation.
(Ord. 1987-61. Passed 1-25-88.)
   1112.08  APPEALS.
   Any contractor whose application for annual renewal of his certificate of
registration has been refused by the Building Commissioner or whose certificate
of registration or annual renewal thereof has been revoked by the Building
Commissioner may appeal the refusal or revocation to the Board of Zoning
Appeals. The appeal shall be perfected by giving notice of such appeal to the
Building Commissioner by certified mail within ten days of the refusal to renew
or receipt of notice of revocation. Upon receipt of the notice, the Building
Commissioner shall notify the Board of the appeal in writing at the next
regular or special meeting of the Board. The Board shall set the appeal for
hearing at the next regular meeting of the Board. Notice of the time and place
of the hearing shall be given to the contractor by the Board by certified mail
directed to the address appearing on the present application form of the
contractor. The notice of the hearing shall inform the contractor that he may
appear at the hearing and present evidence to support his appeal. The Board
shall hear all parties and witnesses for the contractor and the Building
Commissioner and after the hearing shall either affirm, modify or reverse the
order of the Building Commissioner by majority vote of the members present.
Notice of the decision on the appeal shall be given to the contractor by
certified mail directed to the address appearing on the current application of
the contractor.
(Ord. 1987-61. Passed 1-25-88.)
   1112.09  DISPOSITION OF FEES; RECORDS.
   The Building Commissioner is authorized and directed to receive the fees
established in this chapter and, under the supervision of the Director of
Finance, he shall keep an accurate record and accounting of all the fees
received. The fees received shall be deposited in the accounts of the City for
inclusion in the General Fund.
(Ord. 1987-61. Passed 1-25-88.)
   1112.10  HOMEOWNER'S EXCEPTION.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to a homeowner desiring to
perform work on his own premises so long as such work is actually performed by
the homeowner or members of his immediate family, neighbors or friends and the
work is performed without compensation and on premises in which the homeowner
is in actual residence. Any work performed by the homeowner shall be subject to
all of the provisions of the Building Code of the City, and to all inspections
required under the codes.
(Ord. 2007-46.  Passed 5-14-07.)
   1112.99  PENALTY.
   Any person who performs work in the City without first complying with the
provisions of this chapter shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) or imprisoned not more than thirty days, or both.
(Ord. 1987-61. Passed 1-25-88.)
CHAPTER 1113
Licensing Plumbers
1113.01   Definitions.
1113.02   License required.
1113.03   Application for license; bond.
1113.04   Examination for license.
1113.05   Fees; revocation of license.
1113.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate sanitary condition of buildings - see Ohio R.C. 715.26
(A), 715.29
      Power to license plumbers and sewer tappers - see Ohio R.C. 715.27(C)
      Plumbing and sewer permit fees - see BLDG.
1109.14
   1113.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Master plumber" means any person engaged in the business of
plumbing, sewer building and sewer tapping, or who does or contracts or
undertakes to do, either himself or through his servants or employees, plumbing
work, sewer building and sewer tapping.
   (b)    "Sewer tapper" means any person not licensed as a master plumber, who
builds sewers, makes sewer connections or taps sewers.
      (Ord. 1982-33. Passed 5-24-82.)
   1113.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in business, do work, act or undertake to act as a
master plumber or a sewer tapper, without first having obtained a license from
the Building Commissioner.
(Ord. 1982-33. Passed 5-24-82.)
   1113.03  APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; BOND.
   Each applicant for license as a master plumber or sewer tapper shall file
with the Building Commissioner a written application which shall state the
applicant’s name and residence, his business address, his experience in the
business in which he intends to engage, and any other information the Building
Commissioner may require.
   The application shall be accompanied by a bond made payable to the City, in
the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000) with sureties to the approval of the
Building Commissioner, conditioned that the applicant will indemnify and save
harmless the City and the inhabitants thereof from any and all damages on
account of negligence or inadequate or faulty work upon the part of the
applicant, his servants or employees, or on account of his or their failure to
comply with the regulations of the City and the State relating to the same.
(Ord. 1982-33. Passed 5-24-82.)
   1113.04  EXAMINATION FOR LICENSE.
   The Building Commissioner shall examine all applicants for license as master
plumber or sewer tapper, and the examination shall be of a nature and character
as to fairly test the knowledge of the applicant of the essentials of the
business in which he intends to engage.
(Ord. 1982-33. Passed 5-24-82.)
   1113.05  FEES; REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   Upon the filing of the application and bond, if they are in conformity with
the provisions of this chapter, the Building Commissioner is hereby directed to
issue to applicants who have given satisfactory proof of their knowledge of the
essentials of the business in which they intend to engage, a license upon
payment of the following fee:
 
For master plumber's license                                             $50.00
For sewer tapper's license                                             50.00
For master plumber and sewer tapper's license issued to same applicant
                                                                       50.00
   The license shall be for the term of one calendar year, commencing on
January l and ending December 31, but may be renewed annually upon the payment
of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). The Building Commissioner is authorized to
revoke any license where plumbing or sewer work is installed contrary to the
ordinances of the City. Written notice of the revocation shall be served upon
the holder of the revoked license at his last known place of residence, or if
his residence is unknown, then at his residence address given in his
application for the license.
(Ord. 1986-64. Passed 12-22-86.)
   1113.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1105.99 for general Building Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1115
Flood Damage Reduction and Prevention Regulations
1115.01   General provisions.
1115.02   Definitions.
1115.03   Administration.
1115.04   Use and development standards for flood hazard reduction.
1115.05   Appeals and variances.
1115.06   Enforcement.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Construction permits and prohibitions for dams, dikes or levees - see
         Ohio R.C. 1521.06
      Reduction of assessed valuation for reservoirs - see Ohio R.C.
         1521.09
1115.01  GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (a)   Statutory Authorization.  Article XVIII, Section 3, of the Ohio
Constitution, grants municipalities the legal authority to adopt land use and
control measures for promoting the health, safety and general welfare of its
citizens.  Therefore, the City Council of City of Wickliffe, State of Ohio,
does ordain as follows.
   (b)   Findings of Fact.  The City of Wickliffe has special flood hazard
areas that are subject to periodic inundation which may result in loss of life
and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and
governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood protection
and relief, and impairment of the tax base.  Additionally, structures that are
inadequately elevated, floodproofed or otherwise protected from flood damage
also contribute to the flood loss.  In order to minimize the threat of such
damages and to achieve the purposes hereinafter set forth, these regulations
are adopted.
   (c)   Statement of Purpose.  It is the purpose of these regulations to
promote the public health, safety and general welfare, and to:
      (1)   Protect human life and health;
      (2)   Minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control
projects;
      (3)   Minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with
flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public;
      (4)   Minimize prolonged business interruptions;
      (5)   Minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water
and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located
in areas of special flood hazard;
      (6)   Help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the proper use and
