1151.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate building erection - see Ohio R.C. 737.28
      Inspection of buildings for fire and safety - see Ohio R.C. 737.34
      Removal of unsafe structures - see BLDG. Ch.
1159
   1151.01  FIREPROOF DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter “fireproof” means that the outer walls of a building
or structure shall be constructed of brick, stone or concrete. 
(Ord. 1948-18.  Passed 5-24-48.)
   1151.02  FIREPROOF CONSTRUCTION REQUIRED.
   Every building hereafter erected or altered, whether temporary or permanent,
within the Inner Fire District described in Section
1151.03, shall be constructed entirely of fire and waterproof materials, with a
steel carrying frame and all structural parts double fireproofed.
(Ord. 1948-18.  Passed 5-24-48.)
   1151.03  FIRE LIMITS; INNER DISTRICT.
   There is established an Inner Fire District in the City, the limits of which
shall be as follows:  Beginning at a point in the center line of Euclid Avenue
at Euclid Avenue’s most westerly point in this City, that is, at the dividing
line of Lake County and Cuyahoga County; thence south at right angles 200 feet;
thence easterly parallel with the center line of Euclid Avenue to the easterly
lot lines of Harding Drive; thence north at right angles to the center line of
Euclid Avenue; thence westerly along the center line of Euclid Avenue to the
easterly corporate line of Wickiffe; thence north at right angles 200 feet;
thence westerly parallel with the center line of Euclid Avenue to the westerly
line of Lake County; thence south along the westerly line of Lake County to the
place of beginning.
(Ord. 1948-18.  Passed 5-24-48.)
   1151.04  FIRE LIMITS; OUTER DISTRICT.
   There is established an Outer Fire District in the City which shall contain
the territory outside the Inner Fire District as described in Section
1151.03.
(Ord. 1948-18.  Passed 5-24-48.)
   1151.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  See Section
1105.99 for general Building Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1153
Construction Site Requirements
1153.01   Cash deposit required.
1153.02   Debris to be removed.
1153.03   Storage of building materials.
1153.04   Repair of street or sidewalk.
1153.05   Catch basins.
1153.06   Retaining wall.
1153.07   Powers of Building Commissioner.
1153.08   Temporary access drive.
1153.09   Refund of deposit.
1153.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Sidewalk - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
913
         Permits and fees - see BLDG. Ch.
1109
         Building demolition - see BLDG. Ch.
1159
   1153.01  CASH DEPOSIT REQUIRED.
   Before any building permit or any other permit relating to the construction,
alteration or addition of a building is issued, the applicant for the permit
shall deposit with the Building Commissioner, in addition to any other fee or
deposit that may be required by any other section, the following cash amounts:
   (a)   For each single-family dwelling house to be constructed, a cash
deposit equal to one percent (1%) of the estimated valuation, but not less than
three hundred dollars ($300.00).
   (b)   For each multiple-family building to be constructed, a cash deposit
equal to one percent (1%) of the estimated valuation, but not less than five
hundred dollars ($500.00).
   (c)   For each commercial or industrial building to be constructed, a cash
deposit equal to one percent (1%) of the estimated valuation, but not less than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) and not more than five thousand dollars
($5,000.00).
   (d)   For each residential garage to be constructed, a cash deposit of three
hundred dollars ($300.00).
   (e)   For each alteration or addition to a single-dwelling house, multiple-
family building, commercial building or industrial building, a cash deposit
equal to one percent (1%) of the estimated valuation of the alteration or
addition, but not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) and not more than
five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
   (f)   For the demolition of any building, a cash deposit of three hundred
dollars ($300.00). 
(Ord. 1999-51.  Passed 6-28-99.)
   1153.02  DEBRIS TO BE REMOVED.
   During the construction of any building, regardless of its ultimate use, mud
or any other substance or debris shall not be deposited upon any street or
sidewalk of the City by trucks, vehicles, persons or other means employed in
the construction of the building or in the  delivery of material to it or in
any manner connected with the construction.  Upon order of the Building
Commissioner or his assistant or upon order of the Mayor or the Director of
Public Service, the person to whom the receipt is issued for the cash deposit
provided for in Section
1153.01, shall promptly remove the mud or other substance. If the person fails
to do so, the mud or other substance shall be removed and cost of removal
deducted from the cash deposit.
   Upon completion of the structure, all excess material, debris, dirt or any
other substance resulting from its construction shall be removed.
(Ord. 1957-44. Passed 9-9-57.)
   1153.03  STORAGE OF BUILDING MATERIALS.
   All building material shall be maintained and kept on and within the
boundaries of the lot or property upon which a building is being constructed
unless a permit in writing is issued to the contrary.
(Ord. 1957-44. Passed 9-9-57.)
   1153.04  REPAIR OF STREET OR SIDEWALK.
   All curbing, paving or hard surface of any street damaged during the
construction of a building or as a result of such construction shall be
repaired to the satisfaction of the Building Commissioner, his assistant or to
the satisfaction of the Superintendent of Streets.
(Ord. 1957-44. Passed 9-9-57.)
   1153.05  CATCH BASINS.
   No debris, dirt, stones or any other substance created during the
construction of a building shall be deposited in any catch basin.
(Ord. 1957-44. Passed 9-9-57.)
   1153.06  RETAINING WALL.
   If, in the judgment of the Building Commissioner, a retaining wall is
necessary to properly protect adjacent property, such wall shall be constructed
in accordance with the orders of the Building Commissioner.
(Ord. 1957-44. Passed 9-9-57.)
   1153.07  POWERS OF BUILDING COMMISSIONER.
   The Building Commissioner is hereby empowered to make any other order not
herein specifically provided for which in his judgment is appropriate or
necessary to protect the City and to eliminate any condition that might
adversely affect the lives and welfare of the inhabitants of the City, or the
aesthetics of the City, or which, in his opinion, constitutes a nuisance.
   If the orders or directives herein referred to are not promptly executed,
the Building Commissioner is hereby directed to cause the object of such order
or directive to be accomplished and the cost thereof paid from the cash deposit
provided for in Section
1153.01.
   The orders and directives herein referred to shall be final and no appeal
may be had to any other person or body of this City.
(Ord. 1957-44. Passed 9-9-57.)
   1153.08  TEMPORARY ACCESS DRIVE.
   Upon commencement of construction of any new structure in all districts
other than residential districts and prior to the excavation or grading of the
property and prior to the delivery of any construction materials or the placing
of concrete footers on any job site, slag, limestone or other suitable material
shall be installed and maintained as a temporary access drive during
construction of the structure. Such slag, limestone or other suitable material
shall be at least six inches thick and ten feet wide.
(Ord. 1972-9. Passed 3-13-72.)
   1153.09  REFUND OF DEPOSIT.
   When a building is completed to the satisfaction of the Building
Commissioner and all the directives or orders of the persons herein referred to
have been complied with and not earlier than ten days after the completion of
the building and in case of more than one building not earlier than ten days
after the completion of the last of such buildings, the deposit referred to in
Section
1153.01 shall be refunded to the person to whom a receipt was issued diminished
by the amount expended by the City to effectuate any such orders or directives
and less ten dollars ($10.00) for inspection, clerical and other attendant
services.
(Ord. 1982-35. Passed 5-10-82.)
   1153.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1105.99 for general Building Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1155
Garbage Disposals
1155.01   Definitions.
1155.02   Disposer or incinerator required.
1155.03   Disposer specifications.
1155.04   Incinerator specifications.
1155.05   Permit; fee.
1155.06   Right of entry; inspection.
1155.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCE
         Sewer regulations - see S. U. & P. S. Ch.
935
   1155.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Garbage" means every waste or refuse of animal, fruit or vegetable
matter, liquid or otherwise, that attends the preparation, use, cooking,
dealing in or storage of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables.
   (b)    "Mechanical garbage disposer" means a motorized device, suitable for
installation under and in direct connection with a kitchen sink, that
comminutes garbage to such a size as to be readily water-borne and causes the
discharge of such comminuted garbage directly into a sanitary sewerage system.
   (c)    "Garbage incinerator" means a structure or apparatus within which
garbage can be consumed by combustion or dehydration.
   (d)    "Dwelling unit" means a single-family residence, two-family
residence, suite of rooms or apartment in a multiple residence building.
(Ord. 1958-96. Passed 1-12-59.)
   1155.02  DISPOSER OR INCINERATOR REQUIRED.
   (a)    Each dwelling unit, shall, prior to occupation for residence
purposes, be equipped by the building permit applicant, at his expense, with a
properly installed mechanical garbage disposer which conforms to the
specifications in Section
1155.03 or a properly installed garbage incinerator which conforms to the
specifications provided in Section
1155.04. In the case of a multiple residence building, one incinerator of
adequate capacity readily available to occupants of all dwelling units therein
shall be sufficient for the purposes of this chapter.
   (b)    Every building or place, other than a dwelling unit, the construction
or equipment of which is commenced shall, prior to occupancy or use for any
purpose or purposes which result in the production of garbage, be equipped by
the building permit applicant, at his expense, with a properly installed
mechanical garbage disposer which conforms to the specifications provided in
Section
1155.03 or with a properly installed garbage incinerator which conforms to the
specifications provided in Section
1155.04.
(Ord. 1958-96. Passed 1-12-59.)
   1155.03  DISPOSER SPECIFICATIONS.
   For purposes of this chapter the following specifications for mechanical
garbage disposers are prescribed. A mechanical garbage disposer shall:
   (a)    Be of a type tested, approved and listed by the Underwriters'
Laboratories, Inc. and installed in accordance with the provisions of the
National Electrical Code adopted under Chapter
1145. If activated electrically it shall bear evidence of Underwriters'
Laboratory approval;
   (b)    Shred garbage to a substantially uniform size and discharge garbage
at a reasonably uniform rate in a water-borne or fluid form which will flow
readily through standard sink drains, approved traps, drain lines or soil lines
in a manner and consistency which will not cause clogging or stoppage of the
drain line or sewerage lines;
   (c)    Be of substantial construction, adequate capacity for the intended
use and free from electrical or mechanical hazards;
   (d)    Be permanently connected to or appropriately connectable with a drain
to the sewerage system and be free from any cross connection to a water supply.
      (Ord. 1958-96. Passed 1-12-59.)
   1155.04  INCINERATOR SPECIFICATIONS.
   For purposes of this chapter the following specifications for garbage
incinerators are prescribed. A garbage incinerator shall:
   (a)    Be of a type tested, approved and listed by the American Gas
Association in their current Directory of Approved Gas Appliances and Listed
Accessories and be installed in accordance with the provisions of the National
Building Code, 1967 edition, or the current standards of the National Fire
Protection Association or in accordance with published current regulations of
the East Ohio Gas Company. If activated electrically, it shall bear evidence of
Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. approval;
   (b)    Operate so as to completely consume wet or dry garbage by burning it
to ash without causing noisome, offensive or noxious odors, vapors or gases and
without the discharge or emission into the atmosphere of sparks, ash or the
powdered residue of the substance which has been burned.
      (Ord. 1958-96. Passed 1-12-59.)
   1155.05  PERMIT; FEE.
   No mechanical garbage disposer or garbage incinerator shall be installed
without first obtaining a permit from the Building Commissioner. The fee for
the permit is one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) for each mechanical disposer
or garbage incinerator.
(Ord. 1958-96. Passed 1-12-59.)
   1155.06  RIGHT OF ENTRY; INSPECTION.
   The Building Commissioner or his duly authorized representative shall have
authority to enter and inspect buildings and premises for the purpose of
inspecting the installation and use of mechanical garbage disposers and garbage
incinerators.
(Ord. 1958-96. Passed 1-12-59.)
   1155.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1105.99 for general Building Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1156
Commercial Building Maintenance Code
1156.01   Title.
1156.02   Minimum standards; purpose.
1156.03   Scope.
1156.04   Definitions.
1156.05   Applicability.
1156.06   Responsibilities of owner, operator and occupant.
1156.07   Duties and responsibilities.
1156.08   Enforcement.
1156.09   Inspections authorized.
1156.10   Prohibited acts.
1156.11   Notice of violation.
1156.12   Report of violation.
1156.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Residential Building Maintenance Code - see BLDG. Ch.
1158
      Demolition of unsafe buildings - see BLDG. Ch.
1159
      Abandoned buildings - see BLDG. Ch.
1160
   1156.01  TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known as the "Commercial Building Maintenance Code of
the City of Wickliffe" or just "Commercial Building Maintenance Code".
(Ord. 1981-84. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1156.02  MINIMUM STANDARDS; PURPOSE.
   (a)    This Code establishes minimum standards covering the exterior
maintenance and appearance of business, commercial, manufacturing, industrial,
institutional and recreational premises including hotels, motels, motor courts,
lodging houses and industrial camps, hereafter referred to as nonresidential
premises or buildings.
   (b)    The purpose of this Code is to maintain such nonresidential premises
in such condition as will not constitute a blighting or deteriorating influence
on the neighborhood and the community; to fix certain responsibilities and
duties upon owners and operators and distinct and separate responsibilities and
duties upon occupants; to authorize and establish procedures for the inspection
of premises; and to fix penalties for violation of the Commercial Building
Maintenance Code. This Code is hereby declared to be remedial and essential for
the public interest and it is intended that this Code be liberally construed to
effectuate the purposes stated herein.
(Ord. 1985-38. Passed 4-22-85.)
   1156.03  SCOPE.
   The provisions of this Commercial Building Maintenance Code shall be
supplementary to all other provisions of the ordinances of the City relating to
the repair and maintenance of nonresidential buildings and exterior of
premises. In the event of conflict between any provisions of this Code,
including any rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this Code, and any
provisions of the ordinances of the City including any rules and regulations
adopted pursuant to such ordinances, the more restrictive provisions shall
prevail.
   Wherever this chapter purports to regulate structures, signs or conditions
which are otherwise illegal per se due to any other duly enacted ordinances of
the City, such purported regulation herein shall not be considered to
contradict such other ordinance or to condone such otherwise illegal structure,
sign or condition.
   Sections and subsections of this Commercial Building Maintenance Code and
the several parts and provisions thereof, and the holding of any such section,
subsection, part or provision hereof to be unconstitutional, void or
ineffective for any cause shall not affect nor render invalid any other
section, subsection, part or provision thereof.
(Ord. 1981-84. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1156.04  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    The following terms, wherever used herein or referred to in this
chapter, shall have the respective meanings assigned to them unless a different
meaning clearly appears from the context.
      (1)    "Accessory structure" means a structure, the use of which is
incidental to that of the main building and which is attached thereto or
located on the same premises.
      (2)    "Building" means a structure adapted to permanent or continuous
occupancy or use for public, institutional, business, industrial or storage
purposes.
      (3)    "Code" means this Commercial Building Maintenance Code, as
contained in this Title Five of this Part Eleven of the Codified Ordinances of
the City.
      (4)    "Commissioner of Building" or "Building Commissioner" means the
individual designated by the Mayor as being in charge of the Division of
Building Engineering and Inspection in the Department of Public Safety, and
when used herein, shall be construed as though followed by the words "or his
authorized agent or representative ".
      (5)    "Deterioration" means the condition of the exterior of a building
or part thereof, characterized by holes, breaks, rot, crumbling, cracking,
peeling, rusting or other evidence on the exterior of a building of physical
decay or neglect and lack of maintenance.
      (6)    "Garbage" means all kitchen refuse of residences, hotels or
motels, restaurants or other places where food is prepared for human
consumption and all offal from fish, meat and vegetable markets and all
vegetables or organic substances unfit for food that are subject to immediate
decay.
      (7)    "Infestation" means the presence of insects, rodents, vermin or
other pests on the premises which constitute a health hazard.
      (8)    "Occupant" means the person who leases or rents a building,
structure or any portion thereof. The words tenant and occupant shall be
considered synonymous.
      (9)    "Operator" means any person serving as an agent for the owner for
the operation, care and control of a premises or part thereof.
      (10)    "Owner" means any person, who, alone or jointly or severally with
others, shall have legal or equitable title to any premises, with or without
the accompanying actual possession thereof; or shall have charge, care or
control as owner or agent of the owner; or as executor, executrix,
administrator, administratrix, trustee, receiver or guardian of an estate, or
as mortgagee in possession regardless of how such possession was obtained.
      (11)    "Premises" means a lot, plot or parcel of land including the
building or structures thereon.
      (12)    "Rubbish" means all combustible and noncombustible waste
materials, except garbage, and the terms shall include, but not be limited to:
the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other combustible
material, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior, rubber, leather, tree
branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, crockery and
dust.
      (13)    "Structure" means any combination of any materials, whether fixed
or portable, forming a construction, including buildings.
      (14)    "Weathering" means the deterioration, decay or damage caused by
exposure to the elements.
(Ord. 1981-84. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1156.05  APPLICABILITY.
   Every building and the premises on which it is situated shall comply with
the provisions of this chapter, whether or not such building shall have been
constructed, altered or repaired before or after the enactment of this chapter.

(Ord 1981-84. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1156.06  RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNER, OPERATOR AND OCCUPANT.
   (a)    Owners and operators shall have the duties and responsibilities as
prescribed in Section
1156.07 and the regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, and no owner or
operator shall be relieved from any such duty and responsibility nor be
entitled to defend against any charge of violation thereof by reason of the
fact that the occupant is also responsible therefor and in violation thereof.
   (b)    Occupants shall have all the duties and responsibilities as
prescribed in Section
1156.07 and all the regulations promulgated pursuant thereto and the occupant
shall not be relieved from any such duty and responsibility nor be entitled to
defend against any charge of violation thereof by reason of the fact that the
owner or operator is also responsible therefor and in violation thereof.
   (c)    Unless expressly provided to the contrary in this chapter the
respective obligations and responsibilities of the owner and operator on one
hand, and the occupant on the other, shall not be altered or affected by any
agreement or contract by and between any of the aforesaid or between them and
other parties.
(Ord. 1981-84. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1156.07  DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The following duties and responsibilities are hereby imposed upon any owner
or operator of any building covered by the provisions of this chapter.
   (a)    The exterior of the premises and all structures thereon shall be kept
free of all nuisances and any hazards to the safety of occupants, pedestrians
and persons utilizing the premises and free of unsanitary conditions and any of
the foregoing shall be promptly removed and abated by the owner or operator.
The items prohibited hereby shall include, but not be limited to: brush, broken
glass, stump roots, obnoxious growths, filth, garbage, rubbish, trash, refuse,
debris, dead and dying trees and limbs or other natural growth, loose and
overhanging objects and ground surface hazards.
   (b)    Any structure or accessory structure whose exterior surface is bare,
deteriorated, ramshackle, tumble-down, decaying, disintegrating or in poor
repair or whose surface is weathered with dirt and grime or has been impaired
through peeling or flaking of the paint or other protective coating, shall be
repaired, repainted, resurfaced or replaced as follows: all buckled, rotted, or
decayed walls, doors, windows, porches, floors, steps, railings, soffits,
posts, sills, trim and their missing members shall be replaced and put in good
condition; all exterior unfinished surfaces, except masonry, shall be sealed
and painted and conform and match the existing paint or surface covering and
original design or replacement thereof; all exterior walls and surface shall be
properly protected against the weather, where such are defective or lack
weather protection, including lack of paint or surface covering or have
weathered due to lack of proper protective covering; all exterior surface shall
be replaced or repaired in good condition preparatory to repainting or coating;
all bare exterior surfaces which are flaking or crumbling shall be replaced or
sealed in good and workmanlike manner; all new or repaired bare surfaces shall
be painted or coated.
   (c)    Exterior porches, landings, balconies, stairs and fire escapes shall
be provided with bannisters or railings properly designed and maintained to
minimize the hazard of falling and the same shall be kept structurally sound,
in good repair and free from defects.
   (d)    The exterior of the premises and the conditions of accessory
structures shall be maintained so that the appearance of the premises and all
buildings thereon shall reflect a level of maintenance in keeping with
standards of the neighborhood.
   (e)    Premises shall be kept landscaped; lawns, hedges and bushes shall be
kept trimmed.
   (f)    Parking lots shall be kept in a clean, sanitary condition, free from
dust, scrap paper and miscellaneous debris. Such containers as are required for
debris shall be installed.
   (g)    Asphalt or concrete parking lots shall be kept in safe condition free
from chuck holes, depressions, large cracks and disintegrated or deteriorated
areas. If such parking lots are found to be in need of repair, the Building
Commissioner shall cause a written certified notice to be sent to the owner of
such property requiring resurfacing for all or any part thereof. The notice
shall set forth the amount of time for compliance and shall be determined by
the Commissioner considering the extent of repair, cost of repair and
prevailing weather conditions, but in no event less than thirty days nor more
than ninety days.
   (h)    Parking lots without an asphalt or concrete hard surface shall be
kept in safe condition, free from dust, chuck holes, and depressions or large
cracks in the surface of the parking areas.
   (i)    Concrete or asphalt driveway aprons, which are in need of repair or
constitute a condition dangerous to the public using the same, shall be
repaired or replaced in accordance with the specifications of the Director of
Public Service.
   (j)    All permanent signs exposed to public view permitted by reason of
other ordinances or laws shall be maintained in good state of repair. Any signs
which have been damaged or neglected shall be repaired with parts or damaged
sign facings which identify the place of business or products or services
offered on the premises restored to original condition of the entire sign
structure. Any signs which have excessively weathered or faded or those upon
which the paint has excessively peeled or cracked shall, with their supporting
members including poles for support, be removed forthwith or put into a good
state of repair by the owner of the sign. Whenever any structure or part
thereof becomes vacant, all signs which are visible from the exterior and which
no longer apply to a place of business or the products or services offered on
the premises, shall be removed within thirty days. 
   (k)    All display windows or store fronts constructed of plate glass shall
be kept  clean and free of cracks and no storage shall be permitted therein
unless  shielded from public view.
   (l)    All store fronts shall be kept in good repair painted where required
and shall not constitute a safety hazard or nuisance. In the event repairs to a
store front become necessary, such repairs shall be made with the same, similar
or compatible materials used in the construction of the store front in such a
manner as to permanently repair the damaged area or areas. Any cornice visible
above a store front shall be kept painted, where required and in good repair.
   (m)    Any awning or marquee and its accompanying structural members which
extend over any street, sidewalk or other portion of the premises shall be
maintained in good repair and shall not constitute a nuisance or a safety
hazard. In the event such awning or marquee is not properly maintained in
accordance with the foregoing, it shall together with its supporting members,
be removed forthwith. In the event such awning or marquee is made of cloth,
plastic or of similar materials, such cloth or plastic, where exposed to public
view, shall be maintained in good condition and shall not show evidence of
excessive weathering, discoloration, ripping, tearing or other holes. Nothing
herein shall be construed to authorize any encroachment on streets, sidewalks
or other parts of the public domain.
   (n)    For purposes of preservation and appearance, the exterior of every
structure or accessory structure shall be kept in good repair and be kept
painted. All surfaces shall be maintained free from broken glass, loose
shingles, crumbling stone or brick, excessive peeling paint or any other
condition reflective of deterioration or inadequate maintenance.
   (o)    No owner or operator shall occupy, rent or lease or offer for rental
or lease any nonresidential structure or any part thereof which does not comply
with the provisions of this Commercial Building Maintenance Code.
   (p)    The following duties and responsibilities are hereby imposed upon
every occupant of any building covered by the provisions of this chapter:
      (1)    All parts of the premises under the control of the occupant shall
be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. There shall be no accumulation of
rubbish and garbage in open areas.
      (2)    Every occupant shall dispose of all his rubbish in a clean and
sanitary manner by placing it in approved receptacles.
      (3)    Every occupant shall dispose of all his garbage, which might
provide food for insects and rodents, by placing it in approved nonleakable,
nonabsorbent, covered, garbage storage receptacles.
      (4)    Every occupant shall make the necessary arrangements for the
pickup and removal of rubbish and garbage so as not to overload the containers
or receptacles.
      (5)    Every occupant shall be responsible for the elimination of
infestation in and on the premises subject to his control.
         (Ord. 1983-20. Passed 3-28-83.)
   1156.08  ENFORCEMENT.
   The provisions of the Commercial Building Maintenance Code shall be enforced
by the Building Commissioner.
(Ord. 1981-84. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1156.09  INSPECTIONS AUTHORIZED.
   (a)    The Building Commissioner is authorized to make or cause to be made
inspections of the exterior of all structures or premises included in the scope
of this Commercial Building Maintenance Code and all accessory structures to
determine whether such structures or premises conform to the provisions of this
Code.
   (b)    The Building Commissioner shall be supplied with official
identification and shall show such identification, upon request, when entering
upon any premises.
(Ord. 1981-84. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1156.10  PROHIBITED ACTS
   No person shall violate any of the provisions of this Commercial Building
Maintenance Code, or any rule or regulation promulgated hereunder, or fail to
comply therewith or with any written notice or written order issued hereunder
or interfere with, obstruct or hinder the Building Commissioner while
attempting to make inspections.
(Ord. 1981-84. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1156.11  NOTICE OF VIOLATION.
   (a)    Whenever the Building Commissioner finds any nonresidential
structure, accessory structure or premises, or any part thereof to be in
violation of any of the provisions of this Commercial Building Maintenance Code
he shall give or cause to be given or mailed to the owner, operator or occupant
of such structure or premises a written notice stating the violation therein.
Such notice shall order the owner, operator or occupant within a stated
reasonable period of time but not less than ten days, to repair or improve the
structure or premises concerned. Such delivery or mailing shall be deemed legal
service of notice.
   (b)    If the person to whom a notice of violation is addressed cannot be
found within the County after a reasonable and diligent search, then the notice
may be sent by registered mail to the last known address of such person and a
copy of such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the structure or
premises to which it relates. No person shall remove or deface such warning
notice without written permission of the Building Commissioner. Such mailing
and posting shall be deemed legal service of notice.
(Ord. 1981-84. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1156.12  REPORT OF VIOLATION.
   Any person may file a complaint in regard to an alleged violation of the
provisions of this Commercial Building Maintenance Code. All such complaints
shall be in writing and shall be filed with the Building Commissioner who shall
promptly record and investigate such complaint.
(Ord. 1981-84.Passed 10-26-81.)
   1156.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Commercial Building Maintenance Code
or any rule or regulation promulgated thereunder or fails to comply therewith
or with any written notice or written order issued thereunder, or whoever
interferes with, obstructs or hinders the Commissioner of Building while
attempting to make an inspection at a reasonable hour pursuant to this Code
shall for each and every violation or noncompliance be guilty of a misdemeanor
of the first degree and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than
one thousand dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months or both.
Each day during which such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord. 1981-84. Passed 10-26-81.)
CHAPTER 1157
Swimming Pools
1157.01   Definition.
1157.02   Location and area.
1157.03   Illumination.
1157.04   Fences.
1157.05   Drainage.
1157.06   Filtration system.
1157.07   Permits and fees.
1157.08   Application of chapter.
1157.09   Compliance required.
1157.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Fence permits - see BLDG.
1109.20
      Public pools permitted in Institutional and Recreational Districts - see
P. & Z. 1307.20
      Use in residential districts - see P. & Z. 1309.22, 1309.23
   1157.01  DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this chapter, "swimming pool" means a body of water of
artificial construction used for swimming or recreational bathing, which is
over twenty-four inches in depth at any point and has more than 100 square feet
of area on the water surface when filled to capacity, together with the sides
and bottom of such pool and the equipment and appurtenances thereof.
(Ord. 1965-32. Passed 5-10-65.)
   1157.02  LOCATION AND AREA.
   Swimming pools shall be permitted in residential districts, provided the
following conditions are complied with:
   (a)    In one-family and two-family districts, the pool, including walks and
decks, shall not:
      (1)    Be installed or erected in front of any building setback line.
      (2)    Occupy an area greater than ten percent of the lot area.
      (3)    Be nearer to any lot line than the accessory uses permitted in
such districts.
   (b)    In multi-family districts, the pool, including walks and decks, shall
not:
      (1)    Be installed or erected in front of any building setback line.
      (2)    Occupy an area greater than ten percent of the lot area.
      (3)    Be nearer than thirty feet from the main wall, not nearer than
twenty feet from a secondary wall of a multi-family dwelling.
         (Ord. 1965-32. Passed 5-10-65.)
   1157.03  ILLUMINATION.
   Illumination of all pools shall comply with the following requirements:
   (a)    All lighting and wiring shall be in accordance with the National
Electrical Code and all fixtures and equipment shall be UL approved.
   (b)    All lights used for illuminating such pool or the surrounding areas
shall be so designed, located and installed as to confine the direct beams
thereof to the lot or parcel on which the pool is located, and so as not to
constitute a nuisance or undue annoyance to occupants of the abutting property.
   (c)    No lights or other accessories shall project more than ten feet above
the average grade of the pool site.
(Ord. 1965-32. Passed 5-10-65.)
   1157.04  FENCES.
   Every swimming pool including existing pools and except those three feet
high or higher above the surrounding ground and with retractable steps or
ladders shall be completely enclosed by a fence of sturdy construction not less
than forty-two inches in height, measured from the level of the ground where
located, which shall be of such design and construction as to effectually
prevent a child from crawling or otherwise passing through or under such a
fence. Each gate in such fence shall be provided with a secure lock and shall
be kept locked at all times unless the pool is in use. No part of such fence
shall be located between the front yard setback and the street.
(Ord. 1965-32. Passed 5-10-65.)
   1157.05  DRAINAGE.
   Provision shall be made for drainage of the pool into a public storm sewer
where possible, unless there is a ditch or natural watercourse of sufficient
size and gradient adjacent to the pool location to carry off the water
satisfactorily, in which case drainage may be into such ditch or watercourse.
In no case shall the pool be drained, directly or indirectly, onto adjoining
property.
(Ord. 1965-32. Passed 5-10-65.)
   1157.06  FILTRATION SYSTEM.
   All pools, including existing pools, shall be provided with a filtration
system of the type and size approved by the Building Commissioner or by the
Board of Health.
(Ord. 1965-32. Passed 5-10-65.)
   1157.07  PERMITS AND FEES.
   (a)   A permit for the construction, installation, alteration, addition or
remodeling of a swimming pool, or for the construction of a permanent wading
pool, shall be obtained in all cases. The permit shall be issued by the
Building Commissioner, provided the plans and specifications have been approved
as to the structural safety of the construction, installation, alteration,
addition or remodeling, and the plans shall comply with the requirements of
this chapter. Any pool constructed, installed, altered, added to or remodeled
for which a permit is issued shall not be used until the construction,
installation, alteration, addition or remodeling has been approved by the
Building Commissioner.
(Ord. 1965-32.  Passed 5-10-65.)
   (b)   The following schedule of fees shall be charged:
      (1)    Permits for the construction or installation of swimming pools
shall be eighty dollars ($80.00).  Such fee shall include plumbing and sewering
in connection with the construction or installation of the swimming pool.
         (Ord. 2017-26.  Passed 6-26-17.)
   1157.08  APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all private or noncommercial
swimming pools.
(Ord. 1965-32. Passed 5-10-65.)
   1157.09  COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person shall use, operate, repair or maintain any swimming pool in
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or of any lawful order of
the Building Commissioner.
(Ord. 1965-32. Passed 5-10-65.)
   1157.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1105.99 for general Building Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1158
Residential Building Maintenance Code
1158.01   Purpose
1158.02   Scope.
1158.03   Definitions.
1158.04   Rubbish and garbage disposal.
1158.05   Maintenance responsibilities.
1158.06   General maintenance requirements.
1158.07   Maintenance of foundations.
1158.08   Maintenance of roofs, gutters and downspouts.
1158.09   Maintenance of exterior of dwelling structures and accessory
buildings.
1158.10   Pest control.
1158.11   Exterior property areas.
1158.12   Accessory buildings.
1158.13   Resident agent.
1158.14   Responsibility for compliance.
1158.15   Inspection.
1158.16   Identification of inspectors.
1158.17   Notice of violation.
1158.18   Report of violation.
1158.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Commercial Building Maintenance Code - see BLDG Ch.
1156
      Demolition of unsafe buildings - see BLDG Ch.
1159
      Abandoned buildings - see BLDG. Ch.
1160
   1158.01  PURPOSE.
   Within the scope of this chapter, the purpose of this Residential Building
Maintenance Code is to establish minimum standards governing the exterior
maintenance of dwelling structures in such condition as will not constitute a
blighting or deteriorating influence on the neighborhood and the community; to
protect property values and to maintain the character and appearance of the
community and neighborhoods within the community; to fix responsibilities for
owners and occupants of dwelling structures with respect to repair and
maintenance; to establish enforcement procedures; and to fix penalties for
violations.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.02  SCOPE.
   (a)    The provisions of this Residential Building Maintenance Code shall be
supplementary to all other provisions of City ordinances relating to the repair
and maintenance of residential buildings and shall apply to all buildings or
portions thereof, except hotels, motels or motor courts.
   (b)    In the event of conflict between any provisions of this Code,
including any rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this Code, and any
provisions of the ordinances of the City, including rules and regulations
adopted pursuant to such ordinances, the more restrictive provisions shall
prevail.
   (c)    Sections and subsections of this Code and the several parts and
provisions thereof are declared to be independent sections, subsections, parts
and provisions and the holding of any such section, subsection, part or
provision thereof to be unconstitutional, void or ineffective for any cause
shall not affect nor render invalid any other section, subsection, part or
provision thereof.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.03  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and
enforcement of the Residential Building Maintenance Code.
      (1)    "Accessory building" means a secondary or appurtenant building,
the use of which is incidental or accessory to that of the main building, and
which is attached thereto or located on the same premises.
      (2)    "Code" means the Residential Maintenance Building Code, being
Title Five, Chapter
1158 of Part Eleven of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Wickliffe, Ohio.
      (3)    "Commissioner of Building" when used herein, shall be construed as
though followed by the words "or his authorized agent or representative".
      (4)    "Dwelling structure" means a building or structure or that part of
a building or structure used, designed or intended to be used, all or in part,
for residential purposes.
      (5)    "Dwelling" means a building intended or designed to be occupied by
not more than two families living separately and independent of each other.
      (6)    "Garbage" means the animal, vegetable or mineral waste from the
handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food.
      (7)    "Multi-family dwelling" means a building consisting of three or
more dwelling units with varying arrangements of entrance and party walls,
including apartment houses and row houses.
         A.    "Row house" means a multi-family dwelling comprised of dwelling
units attached in a row or group, having party walls and each unit having at
least one separate outside entrance.
         B.    "Apartment building" means a multi-family dwelling comprised of
three or more dwelling units (apartments) arranged side by side and/or one
above the other and each having a separate entrance or entrances connected to a
common outside entrance or entrances.
      (8)    "Occupant" means a person over one year of age, living, sleeping,
cooking or eating and having actual possession of a dwelling structure.
      (9)    "Operator" means a person who has charge, care or control of a
dwelling structure.
      (10)    "Owner" means the owner or owners of the premises including the
holder of title thereto subject to contract of purchase or vendee in
possession, a mortgagee or receiver in possession, a lessee or joint lessees of
the whole thereof or any agent or any other person, firm, corporation or
fiduciary directly in control of the premises. 
      (11)    "Premises" describes a lot, parcel or plot of land, including the
buildings or structures thereon
      (12)    "Rubbish" means combustible waste materials, except garbage. The
term  includes the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other
combustible material, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior, rubber,
leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter,
glass, crockery and dust.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.04  RUBBISH AND GARBAGE DISPOSAL.
   (a)    Every occupant of a dwelling shall dispose of all his rubbish in a
clean and sanitary manner by placing it in approved receptacles. He shall
dispose of all his garbage and other organic waste, which might provide food
for insects and rodents, in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in
approved nonleakable, nonabsorbent, covered garbage storage receptacles. The
rubbish and garbage receptacles described above shall not be stored on the
exterior of a parcel of land at the following locations:
      (1)    In the front yard of a parcel of land extending from the front
wall of a dwelling structure to the front right-of-way property line across the
full width of the lot.
      (2)    In the front yard of an accessory building extending from the
front wall of the accessory building to the front wall line of the dwelling
structure extending from the side wall of the dwelling structure to the full
width of the side yard where a driveway is located, provided the front wall of
the accessory building is located within twenty feet from the rear wall of the
dwelling structure.
(Ord. 1983-1. Passed 1-10-83.)
   (b)    In every multi-family dwelling the owner, operator or his agent shall
be responsible for providing and maintaining suitable approved receptacles,
incinerators approved by the Fire Department or other conveniences for the
disposal of rubbish, garbage, refuse or other waste matter.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.05  MAINTENANCE RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)    Owner. The owner of every multi-family dwelling as defined herein
shall be responsible for the exterior building maintenance thereof in good
repair and safe condition as required by the terms of this Residential Building
Maintenance Code. The owner shall also be responsible for maintaining in a
clean and sanitary condition the shared or common areas of the premises.
   (b)    Occupant. The occupant of any dwelling structure shall be responsible
for maintaining in a clean and sanitary condition that part of the premises
which he occupies and controls.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.06  GENERAL MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    Exterior portions of all dwelling structures shall be maintained in
good repair and shall be capable of performing the functions for which such
structure or part of any feature thereof was designed or intended to be used.
   (b)    The requirements of Sections
1158.04 to
1158.12, inclusive shall be considered in determining the compliance of a
dwelling structure with this section, but such determination shall not be
limited by the requirements of such sections when it is determined by the
Commissioner of Building that there exists any other condition which is
contrary to the intent and purpose of this section.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.07  MAINTENANCE OF FOUNDATIONS.
   (a)    All foundations of every dwelling structure shall be maintained
structurally sound and in good repair.
   (b)    All openings into the foundations of every dwelling structure shall
be protected against the entrance of rodents.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.08  MAINTENANCE OF ROOFS, GUTTERS AND DOWNSPOUTS.
   All roofs of every dwelling structure shall be maintained weathertight and
shall be equipped with gutters and downspouts connected to a public storm
sewer.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.09  MAINTENANCE OF EXTERIOR OF DWELLING STRUCTURES AND ACCESSORY
BUILDINGS.
   (a)    All exterior parts of every dwelling structure, including exterior
walls, parapet walls, decorative additions, chimneys and all other exterior
structures, either above or below the roof line, shall be maintained in a safe
condition, weathertight and so as to resist decay or deterioration from any
cause.
   (b)    Any dwelling structure or accessory building whose exterior surface
is bare, deteriorated, ramshackled, tumbled-down, decaying, disintegrating or
in poor repair shall be repaired or razed.
      (1)    All buckled, rotted or decayed walls, doors, windows, porches,
floors, steps, railings, trim and their missing members and broken glass and
cut or damaged screening for windows and doors shall be replaced and restored
to good condition.
      (2)    All replacements shall match and conform to original design or be
replaced completely.
      (3)    All exterior wood or exterior unfinished surfaces, excluding those
woods approved for use in their natural state, shall be sealed and painted,
surface-covered with other approved protective coating or treated to prevent
rot and decay and shall conform and match the existing paint or surface
covering and original design or replacement thereof. All exterior walls and
surfaces shall be properly protected against the weather where such are
defective or lack weather protection, including lack of paint or surface
covering, or have weathered due to lack of proper protective covering.
   (c)    Any dwelling structure or accessory building whose exterior surface
is deteriorated, decaying, disintegrating, has weathered with dirt and grime or
has been impaired through peeling or flaking of the paint or other protective
coating shall be repaired, repainted or resurfaced.
      (1)    All exterior surfaces shall be replaced or repaired in good
condition preparatory to repainting or coating.
      (2)    All bare exterior surfaces which are flaking or crumbling shall be
replaced or sealed in a good and workmanlike manner.
      (3)    All new or repaired bare surfaces shall be painted or coated.
      (4)    All exterior surfaces weathered with dirt and grime or which are
peeling or flaking shall be painted or covered with approved protective coating
or surface.
   Presentation of evidence that all exterior surfaces have, not more than five
years prior to the date of inspection, been properly prepared and painted with
at least one coat of good exterior paint or covered with other approved
protective coating or surface shall be prima-facie evidence of the exterior
being in good condition
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.10  PEST CONTROL.
   All dwelling structures and the premises thereof shall be maintained free
from sources of breeding, harborage and infestation by insects, vermin or
rodents.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.11  EXTERIOR PROPERTY AREAS
   No owner or operator of any premises shall maintain or permit to be
maintained at or on the exterior property areas of such premises any condition
which deteriorates or debases the appearance of the neighborhood, reduces
property values in the neighborhood, adversely alters the appearance and
general character of the neighborhood, creates a fire, safety or health hazard
or which is a public nuisance. Such conditions include but are not limited to
the following:
   (a)    Broken or dilapidated fences, walls or other structures;
   (b)    Out-of-use or nonusable appliances and automobile parts;
   (c)    Rugs, rags or other materials hung on lines, or in other places on
the premises, which materials are not being used for general household or
housekeeping purposes;
   (d)    Broken, dilapidated or unusable furniture, mattresses or other
household furniture, broken glass, plastic materials, paints, miscellaneous
coverings and/or any other materials, including those described in this
section, placed at or on the premises in such a manner as to be patently
unsightly, grotesque or offensive to the senses;
   (e)    Lawns and landscaping shall also be maintained so as not to
constitute a blighting or deteriorating effect in the neighborhood.
   (f)    No building materials or materials, earth, sand or dirt intended for
use in landscaping or gardening shall be left standing open or covered upon any
premises for a period of time not to exceed six months.
   (g)    Brush, stump roots, obnoxious growths, filth, garbage, rubbish,
trash, refuse, debris, dead and dying trees and limbs or other natural growth,
loose and overhanging objects and ground surface hazards.
      (Ord. 1983-18. Passed 3-28-83.) 
   1158.12  ACCESSORY BUILDINGS.
   All accessory buildings shall be maintained in good repair and free from
health, accident and fire hazards or shall be removed from the premises.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.13  RESIDENT AGENT.
   In any multi-family dwelling in which the owner thereof does not reside, the
owner shall designate a janitor, custodian, agent, operator or other
responsible person who shall be considered the resident agent, reside in such
multi-family dwelling and have charge of the same. Where there exists two or
more such multi-family dwellings on one parcel of land or upon two or more
contiguous parcels of land, one janitor, custodian, agent or operator residing
in any one of such multi-family dwellings may serve as janitor, custodian,
agent or operator for all of such multi-family dwellings.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.14  RESPONSIBILITY FOR COMPLIANCE
   The owner as defined in this Residential Building Maintenance Code shall be
responsible for compliance with all of the provisions of this Code.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.15  INSPECTION.
   The Commissioner of Building is hereby authorized to make or cause to be
made inspections on all dwelling structure exteriors or premises and on all
accessory building exteriors, to determine whether such structures or premises
conform to the provisions of this Residential Building Maintenance Code.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.16  IDENTIFICATION OF INSPECTORS.
   The Commissioner of Building shall be supplied with official identification
and shall show such identification, upon request, when entering upon any
premises.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.17  NOTICE OF VIOLATION.
   (a)    Whenever the Commissioner of Building finds any dwelling structure or
premises, or any part thereof, to be in violation of any provision of this
Residential Building Maintenance Code, he shall give notice in the same manner
as service of summons in civil cases, or by certified mail addressed to the
owner of record of the premises at his last known address or to the address to
which tax bills are sent, or by a combination of the foregoing methods stating
the violations therein. Such notice shall order the owner or operator within a
stated reasonable period of time to repair or improve the structure or premises
concerned.
   (b)    If the person to whom a notice of violation is addressed cannot be
found within the County after reasonable and diligent search, then the notice
may be sent by registered mail to the last known address of that person, and a
copy of such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the structure or
premises to which it relates. Such mailing and posting shall be deemed legal
service of notice.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.18  REPORT OF VIOLATION.
   Any person may file a complaint in regard to an alleged violation of the
provisions of this Residential Building Maintenance Code. All such complaints
shall be in writing and shall be filed with the Commissioner of Building, who
shall promptly record and investigate such complaint.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
   1158.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Residential Building Maintenance Code
or any rule or regulation promulgated thereunder or fails to comply therewith
or with any written notice or written order issued thereunder or whoever
interferes with, obstructs or hinders the Commissioner of Building while
attempting to make an inspection at a reasonable hour pursuant to this Code,
shall for each and every violation or noncompliance be guilty of a misdemeanor
of the first degree and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than
one thousand dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months or both.
Each day during which such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord. 1981-83. Passed 10-26-81.)
CHAPTER 1159
Demolition of Unsafe Buildings
1159.01   Prohibited conditions.
1159.02   Right of entry.
1159.03   Notice to correct; repairs to comply with codes.
1159.04   Appeal to Council.
1159.05   Hearing.
1159.06   Removal or repair required; bids; further appeals.
1159.07   Collection of costs.
1159.08   Fire damaged structures; removal or repair securing fund.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Removal of unsafe structures - see Ohio R.C. 715.26(B), 715.261
      Deposits for demolition - see BLDG.
1153.01
      Abandoned buildings - see BLDG. Ch.
1160
      Demolition of structures in a dangerous condition - see BLDG. Ch.
1162
   1159.01  PROHIBITED CONDITIONS.
   No owner of a building or other structure shall permit it to remain in such
an advanced state of disrepair as to endanger the health, safety and welfare of
the inhabitants of the community or so as to be a public nuisance by reason of
its condition.
(Ord. 1966-96. Passed 11-28-66.)
   1159.02  RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The Building Commissioner shall have free access at any reasonable hour upon
showing appropriate identification when a building is occupied, to inspect,
examine and survey any building, dwelling or structure located within the
Municipality, when he has probable cause to believe it is unsafe or insecure
and therefore dangerous to the inhabitants of the Municipality.
(Ord. 1966-96. Passed 11-28-66.)
   1159.03  NOTICE TO CORRECT; REPAIRS TO COMPLY WITH CODES.
   Upon a determination by the Building Commissioner that any building,
dwelling or structure is in such advanced state of disrepair by reason of
defective or inadequate plumbing or sanitary facilities or faulty or defective
electric wiring, accumulation of debris, filth, rubbish or garbage, general
deterioration in the structure because of age, neglect, exposure to the
elements or vandalism, failure of the exterior enclosure causing exposure to
the elements and general deterioration of the structure, partial damage to the
structure by reason of fire, windstorm or other calamity, or by reason of
deterioration or damage to the foundation, so as to endanger the health, safety
and welfare of the public and is therefore a public nuisance, he shall direct
the owner of such building, dwelling or other structure, in writing by
certified mail, at the last known address of the owner, to effect the repairs
necessary to put the building in a reasonably safe condition, or, if the owner
is unknown or cannot be located, by publishing a notice to effect such repairs
as are necessary to put the building in a reasonably safe condition in a
newspaper of general circulation in the City for a period of not less than two
consecutive weeks. No repairs shall be made unless all requirements of the
Building Code and Zoning Ordinance are complied with.
(Ord. 1966-96. Passed 11-28-66.)
   1159.04  APPEAL TO COUNCIL.
   Within sixty days after receipt of the notice to repair or the last
publication of the notice in a newspaper as provided in Section
1159.03, the owner may appeal a finding by the Building Commissioner that any
such building, dwelling or structure is in such an advanced state of disrepair
as to endanger the health, safety and welfare of the public to Council.
(Ord. 1966-96. Passed 11-28-66.)
   1159.05  HEARING.
   Upon receipt of a written appeal as provided in Section
1159.04, Council shall set the matter for hearing within thirty days after
receiving the notice of appeal and the owner shall have an opportunity to
appear before Council and to present evidence that the building or structure is
not in such an advanced state of disrepair for any of the reasons set forth in
Section
1159.03 as to endanger the health, safety and welfare of the public, and,
therefore, not a public nuisance.
(Ord. 1966-96. Passed 11-28-66.)
   1159.06  REMOVAL OR REPAIR REQUIRED; BIDS; FURTHER APPEALS.
   If no appeal is filed from the finding of the Building Commissioner within
sixty days, or if Council affirms the findings of the Building Commissioner and
determines the building or structure involved to be a public nuisance, Council
shall order the Clerk to advertise for bids for the demolition and removal of
the building, dwelling or structure in accordance with the law, unless the
owner has repaired the same, in accordance with requirements of this Building
Code. No building or structure shall be demolished or removed until notice has
been given as provided in Ohio R.C. 715.26(b).
   In the event that Council is apprised that the owner has appealed its
decision to the Common Pleas Court or any other court having jurisdiction of
such an appeal, the matter will be held in abeyance until further order of the
court.
(Ord. 1966-96. Passed 11-28-66.)
   1159.07  COLLECTION OF COSTS .
   All charges, costs and expenses arising out of or connected with the
demolition and removal of any unsafe building or other structure pursuant to
this chapter shall be paid by the owner of the premises upon which any such
building, dwelling or structure is situated within ninety days after the
demolition or removal thereof. If not paid within such ninety-day period, the
charges, costs and expenses shall be certified to the County Auditor at which
time the lien shall vest, and the Auditor shall place the same on the tax
duplicate of the County with the interest and penalties allowed by law to be
collected as other taxes.
(Ord. 1966-96. Passed 11-28-66.)
   1159.08  FIRE DAMAGED STRUCTURES; REMOVAL OR REPAIR SECURING FUND.
   The City hereby authorizes the procedure described in Ohio R.C. 3929.86(C)
and (D) to be implemented whereby no insurance company doing business in the
State shall pay a claim of a named insured for fire damage to a structure
located within this City unless the applicable provisions of Ohio R.C. 3929.86
are fully complied with. The Building Commissioner is hereby designated as the
officer authorized to carry out the duties of Ohio R.C. 3929.86. The Clerk of
Council shall file a certified copy of this section with the State
Superintendent of Insurance.
(Ord. 1985-12. Passed 4-8-85.)
CHAPTER 1160
Abandoned Buildings
1160.01   Definitions.
1160.02   Prohibited conditions.
1160.03   Notice to abate.
1160.04   Bids.
1160.05   Collection of costs.
1160.06   Parking prohibited; impounding of vehicles.
1160.07   Interpretation.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Removal or repair of unsafe buildings - see Ohio R.C. 715.26(B), 715.261
et seq.; BLDG Ch.
1159 , Ch.
1162
   1160.01  DEFINITIONS
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Abandoned" means the failure to occupy and use a building for at
least three consecutive months in any nine month period.
   (b)    "Building" means a structure which is permanently affixed to the
land, having one or more floors and a roof, being bounded by either open spaces
or lot lines, and used as a shelter or enclosure for persons, animals and/or
property.
       (Ord. 1981-42. Passed 6-29-81.)
   1160.02  PROHIBITED CONDITIONS.
   If any building within the City becomes abandoned, such building shall be
presumed to be a nuisance affecting or endangering surrounding property values
and to be detrimental to the public health, safety, convenience, comfort and
property or the general welfare of the community and shall be abated.
(Ord. 1981-42. Passed 6-29-81.)
   1160.03  NOTICE TO ABATE.
   Whenever the Building Commissioner finds any building to be abandoned, he
shall give notice in the same manner as service of summons in civil cases, or
by certified mail addressed to the owner of record of the premises at his last
known address or to the address to which tax bills are sent, or by a
combination of the foregoing methods, to abate such abandoned condition within
thirty days either by resuming the abandoned use of such building or adopting
and using such building for another use permitted by the City Planning and
Zoning Code, or by razing the building, removing signs and other advertising or
promotion features, with the exception that in any case where an automotive
service station remains abandoned for more than ninety days then the pumps
shall be removed and the underground storage tanks shall be completely removed
rather than filled with inert material, under the supervision of the Bureau of
Fire Prevention, and depressions shall be filled to the grade level of the lot,
provided, however, that if the building is in use at the time notice is given
and remains in use for ninety consecutive days thereafter the provisions of
this section shall not apply and provided, further, that if Council should
determine that an extension may be issued due to economic hardships, the
provisions of this section shall not apply.
(Ord. 1984-85. Passed 10-22-84.)
   1160.04  BIDS.
   Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner to comply with the notice
to abate such abandonment, the Building Commissioner shall advertise for bids
for the demolition and removal of the building in accordance with the law. No
building shall be demolished or removed until notice has been given as provided
in Ohio R.C. 715.26 (B).
   In the event the City is apprised that the owner has appealed its decision
to the Common Pleas Court or any other court having jurisdiction of such an
appeal, the matter shall be held in abeyance until further order of the court.
(Ord. 1981-42. Passed 6-29-81.)
   1160.05  COLLECTION OF COSTS.
   All charges, costs and expenses arising out of or connected with the
demolition and removal of any building pursuant to this chapter shall be paid
by the owner of the premises upon which any such building is situated within
ninety days after the demolition or removal thereof. If not paid within such
ninety day period, the charges, costs and expenses shall be certified to the
County Auditor at which time the lien shall vest, and the auditor shall place
the same on the tax duplicate of the County with the interest and penalties
allowed by law to be collected as other taxes.
(Ord. 1981-42. Passed 6-29-81.)
   1160.06  PARKING PROHIBITED; IMPOUNDING OF VEHICLES.
   The parking of motor vehicles upon the premises on which any building is
unoccupied shall be prohibited and the owner shall post upon such premises
signs at his expense setting forth the prohibition of parking, within thirty
days upon receipt of notice by the Building Commissioner. The Chief of Police
shall designate or approve such signs and designate the location thereof.
Failure to post signs by the owner shall cause the City to post the necessary
signs at the expense of the owner.
   Police officers are authorized to provide for the removal of any vehicles
under the provisions of this section and Section
303.08 of the Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 1981-42. Passed 6-29-81.)
   1160.07  INTERPRETATION.
   In the event that any other provision of the Codified Ordinances conflicts
with any provision contained in this chapter, then the provisions contained in
this chapter shall govern.
(Ord. 1981-42. Passed 6-29-81.)
CHAPTER 1161
Signs
